Question: If the selling price of 7 articles is equal to the cost price of 8 articles, then what is the profit percentage (correct to one decimal place)?
Solution:
Given:
The selling price of 7 articles = The cost price of 8 articles
Formula used:
Gain = SP – CP
Gain% = Gain/CP × 100
Calculation:
The selling price of 7 articles = The cost price of 8 articles
⇒ \(\frac{SP}{{CP}}\) = \(\frac{8}{{7}}\)
Now,
The selling price of an article = Rs. 8
The cost price of an article = Rs. 7
Gain = SP – CP
⇒ Rs. (8 – 7) = Rs. 1
Gain% = (\(\frac{1}{{7}}\) × 100)
⇒ \(\frac{100}{{7}}\)
⇒ 14.3%
∴ The required profit% is 14.3%

Question: If 2x<sup>2</sup> + 5x + 1 = 0, then one of the values of \(x - \frac{1}{{2x}}\) is:
Solution:
Shortcut Trick
2x2 + 5x + 1 = 0
Dividing the number by 2x, we get
⇒ \(x + \frac{5x}{{2x}} + \frac{1}{{2x}}\) = 0
⇒ \(x + \frac{1}{{2x}}\) = \(-\frac{5}{{2}}\)
Using the formula (a - b)2 = (a + b)2 - 4ab, we get
\((x - \frac{1}{{2x}})^2 = (x + \frac{1}{{2x}})^2 - 4 . x. \frac{1}{2x}\)
⇒ \((x - \frac{1}{{2x}})^2 = (\frac{-5}{2})^2 - 2\)
⇒ \((x - \frac{1}{{2x}}) = \pm \sqrt{\frac{17}{4}}\)
∴ The required value is \(\frac{{\sqrt {17} }}{2}\).

Alternate Method
Given:
2x2 + 5x + 1 = 0
Formula used:
(a + b)2 = a2 + b2 + 2ab
(a – b)2 = a2+ b2 – 2ab
Calculation:
2x2 + 5x + 1 = 0
Dividing the number by 2x, we get
⇒ \(x + \frac{5x}{{2x}} + \frac{1}{{2x}}\) = 0
⇒ \(x + \frac{1}{{2x}}\) = \(-\frac{5}{{2}}\)
Now, squaring both sides, we get
⇒ \((x + \frac{1}{{2x}})^2\) = \((-\frac{5}{{2}})^2\)
⇒ \(x^2 + \frac{1}{{4x^2}} + 2 .x . \frac{1}{{2x}}\) = \(\frac{25}{{4}}\)
⇒ \(x^2 + \frac{1}{{4x^2}} + 1\) = \(\frac{25}{{4}}\)
⇒ \(x^2 + \frac{1}{{4x^2}}\) = \(\frac{21}{{4}}\) ----(i)
Now, According to the formula
(a – b)2 = a2+ b2 – 2ab
\((x - \frac{1}{{2x}})^2\) = \(x^2 + \frac{1}{{4x^2}} - 2 .x . \frac{1}{{2x}}\)
⇒ \((x - \frac{1}{{2x}})^2\) = (\(\frac{21}{{4}}\) – 1) [from (i)]
⇒ \((x - \frac{1}{{2x}})^2 = \frac{21 - 4}{4}\)
⇒ \((x - \frac{1}{{2x}})^2\) = \(\frac{17}{{4}}\)
⇒ \(x - \frac{1}{{2x}}\) = ±\(\frac{{\sqrt {17} }}{2}\)
∴ The required value is \(\frac{{\sqrt {17} }}{2}\).

Question: A started a business with a capital of Rs. 54,000 and admitted B and C after 4 months and 6 months, respectively. At the end of the year, the profit was divided among the three in the ratio 1 ∶ 4 ∶ 5. What is the sum (in Rs.) of the capitals invested by B and C?
Solution:
Shortcut TrickRatio of investment × Ratio of time = Ratio of profit
So, Ratio of investment × (12 : 8 : 6) = (1 : 4 : 5)
⇒ Ratio of investment = (1 : 4 : 5) ÷ (6 : 4 : 3) = 1/6 : 4/4 : 5/3
⇒ Ratio of investment = 1/6 : 4/4 : 5/3
⇒ Ratio of investment = 1 : 6 : 10
According to the question
1 unit = 54000 [A's investment]
16 unit [B + C]'s investment = 16 × 54000
∴ [B + C]'s investment = 864000

Alternate Method
Given:
A started a business with a capital = Rs. 54,000
The ratio of the profit = 1 : 4 : 5
Calculation:
Let the capital of B be x and C be y respectively
B invested his capitals = (12 – 4) = 8 months
C invested his capitals = (12 – 6) = 6 months
Now,
According to the question
⇒ \(\frac{54000 .12 . }{{x . 8}}\)= \(\frac{1}{{4}}\)
⇒ x = \(\frac{54000 .12 .4 }{{8}}\)
⇒ x = (54,000 × 6)
⇒ x = 3,24,000
Similarly
⇒ \(\frac{54000 .12 . }{{y . 6}}\) = \(\frac{1}{{5}}\)
⇒ y = \(\frac{54000 .12 .5 }{{6}}\)
⇒ y = (54,000 × 10)
⇒ y = 5,40,000
Now,
The sum of the capitals invested by B and C= Rs. (3,24,000 + 5,40,000)
⇒ Rs. 8,64,000
∴ The required sum of the capitals invested by B and C is Rs. 8,64,000

Question:
The volume of a solid hemisphere is 19,404 cm3. Its total surface area (in cm2) is:
(Take π = \(\frac{{ {22} }}{7}\))
Solution:
Given:
The volume of a solid hemisphere = 19,404 cm3
Formula used:
Volume of hemisphere = 2/3πr3
Total surface area of hemisphere = 3πr2
Calculation:
The volume of a solid hemisphere = 19,404 cm3
2/3πr3 = 19,404
⇒ 2/3 × 22/7 × r3 = 19,404
⇒ 44r3/21 = 19,404
⇒ r3/21 = 441
⇒ r3 = 441 × 21
⇒ r3 = 9,261
⇒ r = 21 cm
Now,
Total surface area of hemisphere = (3 × 22/7 × 21 × 21) cm2
⇒ (3 × 22 × 3 × 21) cm2
⇒ 4158 cm2
∴ The required surface area is 4158 cm2

Question: If 2x – y = 2 and xy = \(\frac{3}{2}\), then what is the value of x3 – \(\frac{{{y^3}}}{8}\)?
Solution:
Shortcut Trick
Hit and Trial method2x – y = 2 and xy = \(\frac{3}{2}\)
If we take y = 1 and x = 3/2 we get both the equation satisfied
So, x = 3/2 and y = 1
Now, we have to find the value of x3 – \(\frac{{{y^3}}}{8}\)
(3/2)3 - 13/8
⇒ 27/8 - 1/8 = 26/8 = 13/4
∴ The required value is \(\frac{13}{4}\)

Alternate Method
Given:
2x – y = 2
xy = \(\frac{3}{2}\)
Formula used:
(a – b)3 = a3 – b3 – 3ab(a – b)
Calculation:
2x – y = 2
Dividing the equation by 2, we get
⇒ (\(x - \frac{y}{{2}}\)) = 1 ....(1)
Cubing both sides, we get
⇒ \((x-\frac{y}{2})^3\) = 13
⇒ x3 – \(\frac {y^3}{{8}}\) – \(\frac{3xy}{2}\) × \((x - \frac{y}{2})\) = 1
⇒ x3 – \(\frac {y^3}{{8}}\) = 1 + \(\frac{3}{2}\) × xy
⇒ x3 – \(\frac {y^3}{{8}}\) = 1 + \(\frac{3}{2}\) × \(\frac{3}{2}\)
⇒ x3 – \(\frac {y^3}{{8}}\) = 1 + \(\frac{9}{4}\)
⇒ x3 – \(\frac {y^3}{{8}}\) = \(\frac{4 + 9}{{4}}\)
⇒ x3 – \(\frac {y^3}{{8}}\) = \(\frac{13}{4}\)
∴ The required value is \(\frac{13}{4}\)

Question: The value of \(0.4\overline 6 + 0.7\overline {23} - 0.3\overline 9 \times 0.\overline 7\) is:
Solution:
Given:
\(0.4\overline 6 + 0.7\overline {23} - 0.3\overline 9 × 0.\overline 7\)
Calculation:
\(0.4\overline 6 + 0.7\overline {23} - 0.3\overline 9 × 0.\overline 7\)
⇒ \(\frac{46 - 4}{{90}}\) + \(\frac{723 - 7}{{990}}\) – \(\frac{39 - 3}{{90}}\) × \(\frac{7}{{9}}\)
⇒ \(\frac{42}{{90}}\)+ \(\frac{716}{{990}}\) – (\(\frac{36}{{90}}\) × \(\frac{7}{{9}}\))
⇒ \(\frac{42}{{90}}\) + \(\frac{716}{{990}}\) – \(\frac{28}{{90}}\)
⇒ \(\frac{462 + 716 - 308}{{990}}\)
⇒ \(\frac{1178 - 308}{{990}}\)
⇒ \(\frac{870}{{990}}\)
⇒ 0.87878787.....
∴ The required value is \(0.\overline {87}\)

Question: In ΔABC, ∠A = 66° and ∠B = 50°. If the bisectors of ∠B and ∠C meet at P, then ∠BPC – ∠PCA = ?
Solution:
Given:
∠A = 66°
∠B = 50°
The bisectors of ∠B and ∠C meet at P
Concept used:
Angle Bisector Theorem - The relative lengths of the two segments that a triangle's side is divided into by a line that bisects the opposite angle
Calculation:

We know that the sum of all the sides of the triangle is 180°
⇒ ∠A + ∠B + ∠C = 180°
⇒ 66° + 50° + ∠C = 180°
⇒ 116° + ∠C = 180°
⇒ ∠C = (180° – 116°)
⇒ ∠C = 64°
Now,
By Angle Bisector theorem,
⇒ ∠BPC = 90° + ∠A/2
⇒ ∠BPC = 90° + 66/2
⇒ ∠BPC = 90° + 33°
⇒ ∠BPC = 123°
Again,
∠PCA = ∠C/2
⇒ ∠PCA = 64/2
⇒ ∠PCA = 32°
Now,
The value of ∠BPC – ∠PCA = (123° – 32°)
⇒ 91°
∴ The required value is 91°

Question: The base of right pyramid is an equilateral triangle, each side of which is 20 cm. Each slant edge is 30 cm. The vertical height (in cm) of the pyramid is:
Solution:
Given:
The base of right pyramid is an equilateral triangle, each side, (a) = 20 cm
Each slant edge, (E) = 30 cm
Concept used:
Circumradius of the equilateral triangle (r) = \(\frac{a}{{\sqrt 3}}\)
h = √(l2 – r2)
Calculation:

According to the question
Each side of an equilateral triangle = 20 cm
We know that, Circumradius of the equilateral triangle = \(\frac{a}{{\sqrt 3}}\)
⇒ AD = \(\frac{20}{{\sqrt 3}}\) cm
Now,
h = √(AE2 – AD2)
h =√[302 – (\(\frac{20}{{\sqrt 3}})^2\)]
⇒ h = √[(900 – \(\frac{400}{{3}}\))]
⇒ h = \(√ \frac{2700 - 400}{{3}}\)
⇒ h = \(√ \frac{2300}{{3}}\)
⇒ h = \(10√ {\frac{{23}}{3}}\) cm
∴ The vertical height of the pyramid is \(10√ {\frac{{23}}{3}}\) cm.

Question: If 847 × 385 × 675 × 3025 = 3a × 5b × 7c × 11d, then the value of ab – cd is:
Solution:
Given:
847 × 385 × 675 × 3025 = 3a × 5b × 7c × 11d
Calculation:
We can write the above numbers as
847 = 11 × 11 × 7 = 112 × 71
385 = 51 × 71 × 111
675 = 3 × 3 × 3 × 5 × 5 = 33 × 52
3025 = 5 × 5 × 11 × 11 = 52 × 112
Now, we have
847 × 385 × 675 × 3025 = 3a × 5b × 7c × 11d
⇒ 112 × 71× 51 × 71 × 111× 33 × 52× 52 ×112= 3a × 5b × 7c × 11d
⇒ 33 × 55 × 72 × 115= 3a × 5b × 7c × 11d
On comparing we get
⇒ a = 3, b = 5, c = 2 and d = 5
Now, We have to find the value of ab – cd
⇒ (3 × 5 – 2 × 5)
⇒ (15 – 10)
⇒ 5
∴ The required value is 5.

Question: A discount of 10% is offered on the price of an article if the payment is made online. An additional discount of 5% is given to credit card holders. A person wishes to buy a watch priced at Rs. 60,000 by paying online through credit card. How much does he need to pay (in Rs.)?
Solution:
Given:
Discount is offered on the price of an article if the payment is made online = 10%
An additional discount is given to credit card holders = 5%
CP of watch by paying online through credit card = Rs. 60,000
Calculation:
CP of watch by paying online through credit card = Rs. 60,000
Discount is offered on the price of an article if the payment is made online = 10%
⇒ Rs. (60,000 × 90/100)
⇒ Rs. 54,000
Now,
An additional discount is given to credit card holders = 5%
⇒ Rs. (54,000 × 95/100)
⇒ Rs. 51,300
∴ The required money he need to pay is Rs. 51,300

Question: If 1 + 2tan<sup>2</sup>θ + 2sinθ sec<sup>2</sup>θ = \(\frac{a}{b}\). 0° < θ < 90°, then \(\frac{a+b}{a-b}\) = ?
Solution:
Given:
1 + 2tan2θ + 2sinθ sec2θ = a/b
Formula used:
(1 + tan2θ) = sec2θ
secθ = 1/cosθ
tanθ = sinθ/cosθ
Calculation:
1 + 2tan2θ + 2sinθ sec2θ = a/b
⇒ 1 + tan2θ + tan2θ + 2sinθ × secθ × secθ = a/b
⇒ sec2θ + tan2θ + 2sinθ × 1/cosθ × secθ = a/b
⇒ sec2θ + tan2θ + 2tanθ × secθ = a/b
⇒ (secθ + tanθ)2 = a/b [(a + b)2 = a2+ b2 + 2ab]
We know that, the reciprocal of (secθ + tanθ) = 1/(secθ – tanθ)
So,
⇒ (secθ + tanθ) × 1/(secθ – tanθ) = a/b
⇒ (secθ + tanθ)/(secθ – tanθ) = a/b
Now, By componendo and dividendo method,
⇒ (secθ + tanθ + secθ – tanθ)/(secθ + tanθ – secθ + tanθ)
⇒ (secθ + secθ)/(tanθ + tanθ)
⇒ (2secθ/2tanθ)
⇒ secθ/tanθ
⇒ (1/cosθ)/sinθ/cosθ
⇒ (1/cosθ × cosθ/sinθ)
⇒ 1/sinθ
⇒ cosecθ
∴ The required value is cosecθ
Shortcut Trick
Concept used:
By Value putting method
Calculation:
If we put the value of θ = 30°
Then,
1 + 2tan2θ + 2sinθ sec2θ = \(\frac{a}{b}\)
⇒ 1 + 2tan230° + 2sin30° sec230° = \(\frac{a}{b}\)
⇒ 1 + 2 × (1/√3)2 + 2 × 1/2 × (2/√3)2 = \(\frac{a}{b}\)
⇒ 1 + 2 × 1/3 + 4/3 = \(\frac{a}{b}\)
⇒ 1 + 2/3 + 4/3 = \(\frac{a}{b}\)
⇒ (3 + 2 + 4)/3 = \(\frac{a}{b}\)
⇒ 9/3 = \(\frac{a}{b}\)
⇒ \(\frac{a}{b}\)= 3/1
Now,
By componendo and dividendo method,
⇒ \(\frac{a+b}{a-b}\) = (3 + 1)/(3 – 1)
⇒ 4/2
⇒ 2
Now,
We know that the value of cosec30° = 2
∴ The required value is cosecθ

Question: If \(\frac{{22\sqrt 2 }}{{4\sqrt 2 - \sqrt {3\, + \,\sqrt 5 }}}\) = \(a + \sqrt 5 b\), with a, b > 0, then what is the value of (ab) ∶ (a + b)?
Solution:
Given:
\(\frac{{22\sqrt 2 }}{{4\sqrt 2 - \sqrt {3\, + \,\sqrt 5 }}}\) = a + √5b
Formula used:
(a + b)2 = a2 + b2 + 2ab
Calculation:
\(\frac{{22\sqrt 2 }}{{4\sqrt 2 - \sqrt {3\, + \,\sqrt 5 }}}\)
Multiplying and Dividing the number \(\sqrt {({3\, + \,\sqrt5})}\) by 2, we get:
⇒ \(\frac{(22\sqrt 2)}{{4√ 2 - \sqrt{(\frac{2 (3 + √ 5)}{2})}}}\)
⇒ \(\frac{(22\sqrt 2)}{{4\sqrt 2 - \sqrt{(\frac{6 + 2\sqrt5}{2})}}}\)
∵ (√5 + 1)2 = 6 + 2√5
⇒ \(\frac{(22\sqrt 2)}{{4\sqrt 2 - \sqrt{(\frac{(\sqrt 5+ 1)^2}{2})}}}\)
⇒ \(\frac{(22\sqrt 2)}{{4\sqrt 2 - \frac{(\sqrt 5 + 1)}{\sqrt2}}}\)
⇒ \(\frac{22\sqrt 2}{{\frac{(4\sqrt 2 . \sqrt 2 - \sqrt 5 - 1)}{\sqrt2}}}\)
⇒ \(\frac{22\sqrt 2 \times \sqrt 2}{{(8 - \sqrt 5 - 1)}}\)
⇒ \(\frac {44}{{7 -\sqrt 5}}\)
On rationalizing we get
⇒ \(\frac {44}{{7 - \sqrt 5}}\) × \(\frac {(7 + √ 5)}{{(7 + √ 5)}}\)
⇒ \(\frac {44(7 + √ 5)}{{7^2 -5}}\)
⇒ \(\frac {44(7 + √ 5)}{{44}}\)
⇒ 7 + √5
comparing the value with a + √5b
⇒ 7 + √5 = a + √5b
⇒ a = 7 and b = 1
Now, The value of (ab) : (a + b)
⇒ (7 × 1) : (7 + 1)
⇒ 7 : 8
∴The required value is 7 : 8.

Question: A student goes to school at a speed of \(5\frac{1}{2}\) km/h and returns at a speed of 4 km/h. If he takes \(4\frac{3}{4}\) hours for the entire journey, then the total distance covered by the student (in km) is:
Solution:
Shortcut Trick
∵ Distance is constant
So, Speed is inversely proportional to Time
Speed Ratio = 11/2 : 4 = 11 : 8
Time Ratio = 8 : 11
According to the question
Total time = 19/4 hours
So, (8 + 11) unit → 19/4 hours
1 unit → 1/4 hour
8 unit → 2 hours
Now, Distance = Speed × Time
Distance of one side = (11/2) × 2 = 11 km
∴ Total distance = 11 × 2 = 22 km.

Alternate Method
Given:
Speed of students goes to school = \(5\frac{1}{2}\) = 11/2 km/h
Speed of students in returns = 4 km/h
Time taken to complete the entire journey = \(4\frac{3}{4}\) = 19/4 hours
Formula used:
Distance = Speed × Time
Calculation:
Let the distance be D km
According to the question
⇒ D/(11/2) + D/4 = 19/4
⇒ 2D/11 + D/4 = 19/4
⇒ (8D + 11D)/44 = 19/4
⇒ 19D/44 = 19/4
⇒ D = 11
Now,
Total time taken = Time taken to going school + Time taken to return
⇒ (11 + 11) km
⇒ 22 km
∴ The total distance covered by the student is 22 km

Question:
Study the given pie charts and answer the question that follows.

Total number of Students appeared = 1200

Total number of students passed = 900
The number of students who passed the examination from institute D exceeds the number of students who appeared from institute A is x. The value of x lies between:
Solution:
Calculation:
Total number of students passed = 900
The students passed in the examination from institutes D = 28%
The number of students who passed the examination from institute D = (900 × 28/100)
⇒ 252
Total number of students appeared = 1200
The students appeared in the examination from institute A = 72°
⇒ (72/360 × 1200)
⇒ 240
Now,
The value of x = (252 – 240) = 12
∴ The value of x lies between 11 and 14

Question: A sum of money becomes Rs. 11,880 after 4 years and Rs. 17,820 after 6 years on compound interest, if the interest is compounded annually. What is the half of the sum (in Rs.)?
Solution:
Shortcut Trick
Ratio of amount = 11880 : 17820
⇒ Ratio of amount = 2 : 3
Let the rate% be R%
According to the question
Amount becomes 2 to 3 in two years
So, 2 (1 + R/100)2 = 3
⇒ (1 + R/100)2 = 3/2
Now, Let the principal be P
So, P (1 + R/100)4 =11880
⇒ P (3/2)2 =11880
⇒ P = 5,280
So, P/2 = 5280/2 = 2640
∴ The required half of the sum is Rs. 2,640

Alternate Method
Given:
Total amount after 4 years = Rs. 11,880
Total amount after 6 years = Rs. 17,820
Formula used:
A = P[1 + (R/100)]n
Where, P = Principal, R = Rate of interest and n = Number of years
Calculation:
Let the sum of money be Rs. x
Total amount after 4 years = Rs. 11,880
⇒ P[1 + (R/100)]n = 11,880
⇒ x[1 + (R/100)]4 = 11,880 .....(1)
Total amount after 6 years = Rs. 17,820
⇒ P[1 + (R/100)]n = 17,820
⇒ x[1 + (R/100)]6 = 17,820 ....(2)
Now,
From equation (1) and (2), we get
⇒ [1 + (R/100)]2 = 17,820/11,880
⇒ [1 + (R/100)]2 = 3/2
Again from equation (1),
⇒ 11,880/x = (3/2)2
⇒ 11,880/x = 9/4
⇒ x = (11,880 × 4/9)
⇒ x = Rs. 5,280
Now,
The half of the sum = Rs. (5,280/2)
⇒ Rs. 2,640
∴ The required half of the sum is Rs. 2,640

Question:
Study the given graph and answer the question that follows.

The total production of fertilisers by country Y in 2017 and 2019 and by country X in 2016 is what percentage of the total production of fertilisers by country Z in 2016, 2018 and 2020?
Solution:
Calculation:
The total production of fertilisers by country Y in 2017 and 2019 and by country X in 2016 = (265 + 285 + 220) = 770
The total production of fertilisers by country Z in 2016, 2018 and 2020 = (320 + 360 + 420) = 1100
Required percentage = (770/1100 × 100)
⇒ (770/11)
⇒ 70%
∴ The required percentage is 70%

Question:
Study the given histogram and answer the question that follows.

The number of persons weighing 55 kg or more but less than 75 kg is what percentage more than the number of persons weighing 80 kg or more but less than 100 kg (correct to one decimal place)?
Solution:
Calculation:
The number of persons weighing 55 kg or more but less than 75 kg = (25 + 35 + 52 + 48) = 160
The number of persons weighing 80 kg or more but less than 100 kg = (38 + 30 + 13 + 9) = 90
Now,
Required percentage = [(160 – 90)/90 × 100]
⇒ (70/90 × 100)
⇒ (700/9)
⇒ 77.8%
∴ The required percentage is 77.8%

Question: The slant height and radius of a right circular cone are in the ratio 29 ∶ 20. If its volume is 4838.4 π cm<sup>3</sup>, then its radius is:
Solution:
Given:
The ratio of the slant height and radius of right circular cone = 29 : 20
Volume = 4838.4 cm3
Formula used:
Volume of cone = 1/3πr2h
h2 = √l2 – r2
Calculation:
Let the ratio of the slant height and radius of right circular cone be 29x and 20x respectively
According to the question
h = √l2 – r2
⇒ h = √29x2 – 20x2
⇒ h = √(841 – 400)x2
⇒ h = √441x2
⇒ h = 21x cm
Now,
Volume of cone = 4838.4 π
⇒ (1/3 × π × 400x2 × 21x) = 4838.4 π
⇒ x3 = (172.8/100)
⇒ x3 = (1728/1000)
⇒ x = 12/10
Now,
The radius = 20x = (20 × 12/10) cm
⇒ 24 cm
∴ The required radius is 24 cm

Question: If x<sup>2</sup> – \({\sqrt 7x }\) + 1 = 0, then what is the value of \({x^5} + \frac{1}{{{x^5}}}\) ?
Solution:
Given:
x2 – √7x + 1 = 0
Formula used:
\(({x} + \frac{1}{{{x}}})^2\) = x2 + \(\frac {1}{{x^2}}\) + \(\frac{2 .x .1}{{x}}\)
\(({x} + \frac{1}{{{x}}})^3\) = x3 + \(\frac{1}{{x ^3}}\) +\(\frac{3.x.1}{{x}}\) × \(({x} + \frac{1}{{{x}}})\)
\({x^5} + \frac{1}{{{x^5}}}\) = \(({x^2} + \frac{1}{{{x^2}}})\)\(({x^3} + \frac{1}{{{x^3}}})\) – \(({x} + \frac{1}{{{x}}})\)
Calculation:
x2 – √7x + 1 = 0
⇒ x2 + 1 = √7x
⇒ \(({x} + \frac{1}{{{x}}})\) = √7
Now,
Squaring both sides, we get
\(({x} + \frac{1}{{{x}}})^2\) = (√7)2
⇒ x2 + \(\frac {1}{{x^2}}\) + \(\frac{2 .x .1}{{x}}\) = 7
⇒ x2 + \(\frac {1}{{x^2}}\) + 2 = 7
⇒ x2 + \(\frac {1}{{x^2}}\) = (7 – 2)
⇒ x2 + \(\frac {1}{{x^2}}\)= 5
Now,
Cubing both sides, we get
\(({x} + \frac{1}{{{x}}})^3\) = (√7)3
⇒ x3 + \(\frac{1}{{x ^3}}\) +\(\frac{3.x.1}{{x}}\) × \(({x} + \frac{1}{{{x}}})\) = 7√7
⇒ x3 + \(\frac{1}{{x ^3}}\) + 3 × √7 = 7√7
⇒ x3 + \(\frac{1}{{x ^3}}\) + 3√7 = 7√7
⇒ x3 + \(\frac{1}{{x ^3}}\) = (7√7 – 3√7)
⇒ x3 + \(\frac{1}{{x ^3}}\) = 4√7
Now,
The value of \({x^5} + \frac{1}{{{x^5}}}\)
⇒ \(({x^2} + \frac{1}{{{x^2}}})\)\(({x^3} + \frac{1}{{{x^3}}})\) – \(({x} + \frac{1}{{{x}}})\)
⇒ (5 × 4√7) – √7
⇒ 20√7 – √7
⇒ 19√7
∴ The required value is 19√7

Question: ABCD is a cyclic quadrilateral and BC is a diameter of the circle. If ∠DBC = 29°, then ∠BAD = ?
Solution:
Given:
∠DBC = 29°
Concept used:
Angle in a semicircle is a right angle.
We know that sum of all the sides of triangles is 180°
The opposite angles in a cyclic quadrilateral is 180°
Calculation:

According to the question
∠DBC = 29°
∠BDC = 90° [Angle in a semicircle is 90°]
We know that sum of all the sides of triangles is 180°
⇒ ∠DBC + ∠BDC + ∠BCD = 180°
⇒ 29° + 90° + ∠BCD = 180°
⇒ 119° + ∠BCD = 180°
⇒ ∠BCD = (180° – 119°)
⇒ ∠BCD = 61°
Now,
We know that, the opposite angles in a cyclic quadrilateral is 180°
So,
⇒ ∠BAD + ∠BCD = 180°
⇒ ∠BAD + 61° = 180°
⇒ ∠BAD = (180° – 61°)
⇒ ∠BAD = 119°
∴ The required value of ∠BAD is 119°

Question: The monthly expenses of a person are \(66\frac{2}{3}\%\) more than her monthly savings. If her monthly income increases by 44% and her monthly expenses increase by 60%, then there is an increase of Rs. 1,040 in her monthly savings. What is the initial expenditure (in Rs.)?
Solution:
Shortcut Trick66.66% = 2/3
According to the question,
If we take saving = 3 units then
Expenditure will be 5 units
Hence, Income = 8 units
Now, from ratio method
Income → [25 : 36] × (8/25) <--- to make Income 8 unit
Exp → [5 : 8]
New Ratio after multiplying
Income → [8 : 288/25]
Exp .→ [5 : 8]
---------------------------------------------
Saving → 3 : 88/25
But according to the question
(88/25 - 3) unit → Rs. 1040
1 unit → Rs. 2000
∴ The Initial expenditure (5 units) → Rs. 10,000

Alternate Method
Given:
The monthly expenses of a person are \(66\frac{2}{3}\%\) more than her monthly savings
Her monthly income increases = 44%
Her monthly expenses increases = 60%
There is an increase in her monthly savings = Rs. 1040
Formula used:
Income = Expenditure + Saving
Saving = Income – Expenditure
Calculation:
Let the number be x
The monthly expenses of a person are \(66\frac{2}{3}\%\) more than her monthly savings
⇒ \(66\frac{2}{3}\%\) = (\(\frac{200}{{300}}\)x)
⇒ \(\frac{2}{{3}}\)x
So,
The monthly saving of a person = 3x
The monthly expenditure of the person = 5x
The monthly income of the person = (5x + 3x) = 8x
Now,
Her monthly income increases = 44%
⇒ (8x × \(\frac{144}{{100}}\))
⇒ \(\frac{1152x}{{100}}\)
⇒ 11.52x
Now,
Her monthly expenses increases = 60%
⇒ (5x × \(\frac{160}{{100}}\))
⇒ \(\frac{800x}{{100}}\)
⇒ 8x
The savings of the person = (11.52x – 8x) = 3.52x
According to the question
There is an increase in her monthly savings = Rs. 1040
⇒ (3.52x – 3x) = 1040
⇒ 0.52x = 1040
⇒ x = \(\frac{1040}{{0.52}}\)
⇒ x = 2000
Now,
The initial expenditure of a person = 5x = (5 × 2000)
⇒ Rs. 10,000
∴ The required expenditure is Rs. 10,000

Question: Two pipes A and B can fill a cistern in \(12\frac{1}{2}\) hours and 25 hours, respectively. The pipes were opened simultaneously, and it was found that, due to leakage in the bottom, it took one hour 40 minutes more to fill the cistern. If the cistern is full, in how much time (in hours) will the leak alone empty 70% of the cistern?
Solution:
Shortcut Trick
Let the capacity of the tank be 25 units
The efficiency of A = 2 unit/hr
The efficiency of B = 1 unit/hr
Combined Efficiency of (A + B) = 3 unit/hr
Time taken by (A + B) to fill the tank = 25/3 hr
Due to a leak time taken = 25/3 + 5/3 hours = 10 hours
Combined efficiency of A, B and leak = 25/10 = 2.5
Efficiency of Leak = 2.5 - 3 = -0.5 unit
Required time to empty 70% of the tank = (25 × 0.7)/(0.5)
⇒ 35 hours
∴ The required time is 35 hours.

Alternate Method
Given:
Pipe A can fill a cistern = \(12\frac{1}{2}\) hours = 25/2 hours
Pipe B can fill a cistern = 25 hours
Calculation:
Pipe A can fill a cistern = 25/2 hours
Work is done by Pipe A in 1 hour = 2/25
Pipe B can fill a cistern = 25 hours
Work is done by Pipe B in 1 hour = 1/25
Work done by both pipes in 1 hour together = (\(\frac{2}{{25}}\) + \(\frac{1}{{25}}\)) = \(\frac {3}{{25}}\)
Time taking together by both the pipes = \(\frac {25}{{3}}\) hours
Now,
⇒ (\(\frac {25}{{3}}\) × 60) = 500 min = 8 hour 20 min [1 hour = 60 min]
Due to leak = (8 hours 20 min + 1 hour 40 min) = 10 hours
Due to the leak was done by the pipe in 1 hour = (\(\frac {3}{{25}}\) – \(\frac {1}{{10}}\))
⇒\(\frac {6 - 5}{{50}}\) = \(\frac {1}{{50}}\)
Time taking to empty the 70% of the cistern = (50 × \(\frac {70}{{100}}\))
⇒ 35 hours
∴ The required time is 35 hours.

Question: A sum of Rs. 46,800 is divided among A, B, C and D in such a way that the ratio of the combined share of A and D to the combined share of B and C is 8 ∶ 5. The ratio of the share of B to that of C is 5 ∶ 4. A receives Rs. 18,400. If x is the difference between the shares of A and B and y is the difference between the shares of C and D, then what is the value of (x – y) (in Rs.)?
Solution:
Given:
Total sum = Rs. 46,800
The ratio of the combined share of A and D to the combined share of B and C = 8 : 5
The ratio of the share of B to that of C = 5 : 4
A receives = Rs. 18,400
Calculation:
The ratio of the combined share of A and D to the combined share of B and C = 8 : 5
⇒ (A + D) : (B + C) = 8 : 5
The ratio of the share of B to that of C = 5x : 4x
⇒ (5x + 4x) = 9x
Now,
We multiply the combined share of A and D and the combined share of B and C by 9
⇒ (8 : 5) × 9
⇒ 72 : 45
The share of A and D = 72 units
The share of B and C = 45 units
According to the question
The ratio of the share of B to that of C
⇒ 9x = 45 units
⇒ x = 5 units
The share of B = 5x = (5 × 5) = 25 units
The share of C = 4x = (4 × 5) = 20 units
Now,
The combined sum of A to D and B to C = (72 + 45) units = 117 units
⇒ 117 units = 46,800
⇒ 1 unit = (46,800/117)
⇒ Rs. 400
Now,
B receives = (25 × 400) = Rs. 10,000
C receives = (20 × 400) = Rs. 8,000
Now,
D receives = Total sum – (A + B + C)
⇒ 46,800 – (18,400 + 10,000 + 8,000)
⇒ 46,800 – 36,400
⇒ Rs. 10,400
⇒ D receives = Rs. 10,400
Now,
x is the difference between the shares of A and B = Rs. (18,400 – 10,000)
⇒ x = Rs. 8,400
y is the difference between the shares of C and D = Rs. (10,400 – 8000)
⇒ y = Rs. 2,400
Now,
The value of (x – y) = Rs. (8,400 – 2,400)
⇒ Rs. 6,000
∴ The required value is Rs. 6000.
Alternate Method According to the question,
A + D : B + C = 8 : 5
⇒ 8 units + 5 units = 13 units = 46,800
⇒ 1 unit = 46,800/13 = 3600
Now we can say that,
⇒ A + D = 8 units = 8 × 3600 = 28,800
and B + C = 5 units = 5 × 3600 = 18,000
Now, according to the question,
B : C = 5 : 4
⇒ 5 units + 4 units = 9 units = 18000
⇒ 1 unit = 18000/9 = 2000
We can say that,
⇒ B = 5 × 2000 = 10,000
and C = 4 × 2000 = 8,000
Also, A = 18,400
Thus we can say that,
⇒ D = 28,800 - 18,400 = 10,400
Now, x = A - B = 18,400 - 10,000 = 8,400
and y = 10,400 - 8,000 = 2,400
⇒ X - Y = 8,400 - 2,400 = 6,000
∴ The required value is Rs. 6000.

Question: The ratio of the distance between two places A and B to the distance between places B and C is 3 ∶ 5. A man travels from A to B at a speed of x km/h and from B to C at a speed of 50 km/h. If his average speed for the entire journey is 40 km/h, then what is the value of (x – 10) : ( x + 1)?
Solution:
Given:
The ratio of the distance between two places A and B to the distance between places B and C = 3 : 5
A man travels from A to B at a speed = x km/hr
A man travels from B to C at a speed = 50 km/hr
His average speed for the entire journey = 40 km/hr
Formula used:
Average speed = Total distance/Total time taken
Calculation:
Let the distance between A and B to the distance between B and C be 3a and 5a respectively
According to the question
Time taken by man to travel from A and B at a speed of x km/hr = 3a/x
Time taken by man to travel from B and C at a speed of 50 km/hr = 5a/50
⇒ a/10
Average speed of the entire journey = Total distance/Total time taken
⇒ (3a + 5a)/(3a/x + a/10) = 40
⇒ 8a/(3a/x + a/10) = 40
⇒ 8a = 40a(3/x + 1/10)
⇒ 1/5 = (30 + x)/10x
⇒ 2x = 30 + x
⇒ (2x – x) = 30
⇒ x = 30 km/hr
Now,
The value of (x – 10) : ( x + 1) = (30 – 10) : (30 + 1)
⇒ 20 : 31
∴ The required value is 20 : 31

Question: Alloy A contains metals x and y only in the ratio 5 ∶ 2, while alloy B contains them in the ratio 3 ∶ 4. Alloy c is prepared by mixing alloys A and B in the ratio 4 ∶ 5. the percentage of x in alloy C is:
Solution:
Shortcut TrickAlloy A = 5 : 2 --sum--> 7] × 4
Alloy B = 3 : 4 --sum--> 7] × 5
-----------------------------------------------
Since the sum of quantity is same so multiplication by 4 and 5 just because the amount of A and B are taken in the ratio 4 : 5
Alloy A = 20 : 8
Alloy B = 15 : 20
---------------------------
Alloy C = 35 : 28 = 5 : 4
Total quantity = 5 + 4 = 9
Required % = (5/9) × 100% = \(55\frac{5}{9}\)
∴ The required percentage of x in alloy C is \(55\frac{5}{9}\).

Alternate Method
Given:
The mixture of x and y in Alloy A = 5 : 2
The mixture of x and y in Alloy B = 3 : 4
The ratio of A and B in alloy C = 4 : 5
Calculation:
Let the quantity of metal x in alloy C be x
Quantity of metal x in alloy A = \(\frac{5}{{7}}\)
Quantity of metal y in alloy A = \(\frac{2}{{7}}\)
Quantity of metal x in alloy B = \(\frac{3}{{7}}\)
Quantity of metal y in alloy B = \(\frac{4}{{7}}\)
According to the question
The ratio of x and y in alloy C = [(\(\frac{5}{{7}}\) × 4) + (\(\frac{3}{{7}}\) × 5)]/[(\(\frac{2}{{7}}\) × 4) + (\(\frac{4}{{7}}\) × 5)]
⇒ (\(\frac{20}{{7}}\) + \(\frac{15}{{7}}\))/(\(\frac{8}{{7}}\) + \(\frac{20}{{7}}\))
⇒ (\(\frac{35}{{7}}\))/(\(\frac{28}{{7}}\))
⇒ (\(\frac{35}{{7}}\) × \(\frac{7}{{28}}\)
⇒ \(\frac{5}{{4}}\)
Now,
Quantity of x in alloy C = \(\frac{5}{{(5 + 4)}}\)
⇒ \(\frac{5}{{9}}\)
Percentage of x in alloy C = (\(\frac{5}{{9}}\) × 100)
⇒ \(\frac{500}{{9}}\)
⇒ \(55\frac{5}{9}\)
∴ The required percentage of x in alloy C is \(55\frac{5}{9}\)
Shortcut Trick

Question:
The curved surface area and the volume of a cylindrical object are 88 cm2 and 132 cm3, respectively. The height (in cm) of the cylindrical object is:
(Take π = \(\frac{{22}}{7}\))
Solution:
Given:
The curved surface area of cylinder = 88 cm2
The volume of the cylinder = 132 cm3
Formula used:
Curved surface area of cylinder = 2πrh
Volume of the cylinder = πr2h
Calculation:
According to the question
The curved surface area of cylinder/Volume of the cylinder = \(\frac{88}{{132}}\)
⇒ 2πrh/πr2h = \(\frac{88}{{132}}\)
⇒ \(\frac{2}{{r}}\) = \(\frac{2}{{3}}\)
⇒ r = 3 cm
Now,
Putting the value of r in Curved surface area of cylinder
⇒ 2 × \(\frac{22}{{7}}\) × 3 × h = 88
⇒ \(\frac{132h}{{7}}\) = 88
⇒ \(\frac{3h}{{7}}\) = 2
⇒ 3h = 14
⇒ h = \(\frac{14}{{3}}\)
⇒ h = \(4\frac{2}{3}\)
∴ The height of the cylindrical object is \(4\frac{2}{3}\)

Question: In an examination, average marks of a student per paper were 71. If he would have obtained 35 more marks in science; 11 more marks in history and 4 more marks in computer science, his average marks per paper would have been 76. How many papers were there in the examination?
Solution:
Shortcut TrickLet the number of papers be n
Increaed marks = 35 + 11 + 4 = 50 marks
Increase in average = 76 - 71 = 5
According to the concept of average
Increase marks is equally divided into each papers
So, n × 5 = 50
⇒ n = 10
∴ Total number of papers in exam is 10.
Alternate Method
Given:
The average marks of a student per paper = 71
The numbers obtained in science = 35 marks more
The numbers obtained in history = 11 marks more
The numbers obtained in computer science = 4 marks more
Calculation:
Let the number of papers in the examination be x
According to the question
⇒ 76 × x = 71 × x + 35 + 11 + 4
⇒ 76x = 71x + 50
⇒ (76x – 71x) = 50
⇒ 5x = 50
⇒ x = 10
∴ There were 10 papers in the examination

Question: If a 10-digit number 75462A97B6 is divisible by 72, then the value of \(\rm \sqrt {8A - 4B}\) is:
Solution:
Given:
The 10-digit number = 75462A97B6 is divisible by 72
Concept used:
When a number is divisible by 72, then it must be divisible by 8 × 9
Divisibility rule of 8 - If the last three digits of a number are divisible by 8, then the number is completely divisible by 8.
Divisibility rule of 9 - If the sum of digits of the number is divisible by 9, then the number itself is divisible by 9.
Calculation:
The 10-digit number = 75462A97B6
When a number is divisible by 8, then the last three digit number is divisible by 8
The last three-digit number = 7B6
When, B = 3 or B = 7
Case I:
If we take B = 3
Then the number becomes 75462A9736
Now, When a number is divisible by 9,
Then the sum of its digits is divisible by 9.
⇒ (7 + 5 + 4 + 6 + 2 + A + 9 + 7 + 3 + 6)
⇒ 49 + A
Now, A can be 5
So, \(\rm \sqrt {8A - 4B}\) = √(8 × 5 - 4 × 3) = √28
Case II.
If we take B = 7
Then the number becomes 75462A9776
Now, When a number is divisible by 9,
Then the sum of its digits is divisible by 9.
⇒ (7 + 5 + 4 + 6 + 2 + A + 9 + 7 + 7 + 6)
⇒ 53 + A
Now, A can be 1
So, \(\rm \sqrt {8A - 4B}\) = √(8 × 1 - 4 × 7) = √-20
Which is not possible.
∴ The correct answer is √28.

Question: ABCD is a quadrilateral in which AB ∥ DC. E and F are the midpoints of the diagonals AC and BD, respectively. If AB = 18 cm and CD = 6 cm, then EF = ?
Solution:
Given:
ABCD is a quadrilateral in which AB ∥ DC.
E and F are the midpoints of the diagonals AC and BD
AB = 18 cm
CD = 6 cm
Concept used:
The length of line joining midpoints of the diagonals is half the difference of the length of parallel sides of the trapezium.
Calculation:

ABCD is a quadrilateral in which AB ∥ DC.
E and F are the midpoints of the diagonals AC and BD
We know that, the length of line joining midpoints of the diagonals is half the difference of the length of parallel sides of the trapezium.
So,
⇒ EF = \(\frac{1}{{2}}\)(Difference of its parallel sides)
⇒ EF = \(\frac{1}{{2}}\)(AB – DC)
⇒ EF = \(\frac{1}{{2}}\)(18 – 6)
⇒ EF = \(\frac{1}{{2}}\) × 12
⇒ EF = 6 cm
∴ The value of EF is 6 cm

Question: AB and CD are two chords in a circle with centre O and AD is a diameter. AB and CD produced meet at a point P outside the circle. If ∠APD = 25° and ∠DAP = 39°, then the measure of ∠CBD is:
Solution:
Given:
AB and CD are two chords in a circle with centre O and AD is a diameter
AB and CD produced meet at a point P outside the circle
∠APD = 25°
∠DAP = 39°
Concept used:
Exterior angle theorem - An exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of its two opposite non-adjacent interior angles.
The angle subtended from a diameter is 90°
The opposite angles of a triangle is equal
Calculation:


According to the question
We know that, an exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of its two opposite non-adjacent interior angles.
So, In ΔADP
∠ADC = ∠DAP + ∠DPA
⇒ ∠ADC = 25° + 39°
⇒ ∠ADC = 64°
Now,
Angles in the same segment are equal
So, ∠ADC = ∠ABC = 64° ----(I)
Since, AD is a diameter
So, ∠ABD = 90°
⇒ ∠ABC + ∠CBD = 90°
⇒ 64° + ∠CBD = 90° [From (i)]
⇒ ∠CBD = 26°
∴ The value of ∠CBD is 26° .

Question: The ratio of the incomes of A and B in the last year was 4 ∶ 3. The ratios of their individual incomes in the last year and the present year are 3 ∶ 4 and 5 ∶ 6, respectively. If their total income in the present year is Rs. 24.12 lakhs, then the sum of the income (in Rs. lakhs) of A in the last year and that of B in the present year is:
Solution:
Shortcut Trick
The incomes of A and B in the last year = 4 ∶ 3
We should write this ratio as 15 × (4 : 3) = 60 : 45
15 is the LCM of 3 [from ratio 3 : 4] and 5 [from ratio 5 : 6]
Now, Present income of A = 60 × 4/3 = 80
Present income of B = 45 × 6/5 = 54
According to the question
(80 + 54) unit → 24.12 lakh
1 unit → 0.18 lakh
Required value = (60 + 54) unit
∴ Required value = 114 × 0.18 lakh = 20.52 lakh.

Alternate Method
Given:
The ratio of the incomes of A and B in the last year = 4 : 3
The ratios of their individual incomes in the last year = 3 : 4
The ratios of their individual incomes in the present year = 5 : 6
Total income in the present year = Rs. 24.12 lakhs
Calculation:
The ratio of the incomes of A and B in the last year = 4x : 3x ...(1)
The ratio of income of A the last year to the present year = 3x : 4x ....(2)
The ratio of income of B the last year to the present year = 5x : 6x ....(3)
To equate last year income of A and B in the above equation we will multiply 15 in equation (1) and 20 in equation (2) and 9 in equation (3)
Now,
The ratio of the incomes of A and B in the last year = 60x : 45x .....(4)
The ratio of income of A the last year to the present year = 60x : 80x ....(5)
The ratio of income of B the last year to the present year = 45x : 54x ...(6)
Now,
From equation (5) and (6), we get
The ratio of present income of A to the income of B = 80x : 54x
According to the question
⇒ (80x + 54x) = 24.12 lakh
⇒ 134x = 24.12 lakh
⇒ x = 24.12/134
⇒ x = 0.18
Now,
The sum of the income of A in the last year and that of B in the present year = (60 × 0.18 + 54 × 0.18)
⇒ Rs. (10.8 + 9.72)
⇒ Rs. 20.52 lakhs
∴ The required sum is Rs. 20.52 lakhs

Question: In ΔABC, O is the point of intersection of the bisectors of ∠B and ∠A. If ∠BOC = 10<sup>8</sup>°, then ∠BAO = ?
Solution:
Given:
In ΔABC, O is the point of intersection of the bisectors of ∠B and ∠A
∠BOC = 108°
Concept used:
If the bisector of ∠ABC and ∠ACB of a triangle ABC meet at a point O then, ∠BOC = 90° + \(\frac{1}{{2}}\)∠A
Angle bisector theorem - An angle bisector of an angle of a triangle divides the opposite side into two parts that are proportional to the other two sides of the triangle.
Calculation:

If the bisector of ∠ABC and ∠ACB of a triangle ABC meet at a point O then, ∠BOC = 90° + \(\frac{1}{{2}}\)∠A
⇒ 108° = 90° + \(\frac{1}{{2}}\)∠A
⇒ \(\frac{1}{{2}}\)∠A = (108° – 90°)
⇒ \(\frac{1}{{2}}\)∠A = 18°
⇒ ∠A = 36°
Now,
We know that, an angle bisector of an angle of a triangle divides the opposite side into two parts that are proportional to the other two sides of the triangle.
So,
⇒ ∠BAO = \(\frac{∠ A}{{2}}\)
⇒ ∠BAO = \(\frac{36}{{2}}\)
⇒ ∠BAO = 18°
∴ The value of ∠BAO = 18°
Confusion Points Bisector of ∠A, ∠B and ∠C will intersect at a single point i.e O.

Question: A, B and C invested their capitals in the ratio 2 ∶ 3 ∶ 5. The ratio of months for which they invested is 4 ∶ 2 ∶ 3, respectively. If the difference between the profit shares of A and B is Rs. 1,86,000, then C's share of profit (in Rs.) is:
Solution:
Given:
The ratio of capitals invested by A, B and C = 2 : 3 : 5
The ratio of months for which they invested = 4 : 2 : 3
The difference between the profit shares of A and B = Rs. 1,86,000
Formula used:
Profit = Time × Money
Calculation:
The ratio of profit of A, B and C = (2 × 4) : (3 × 2) : (5 × 3)
⇒ 8 : 6 : 15
Let the ratio of profit of A, B and C be 8x : 6x : 15x respectively
According to the question
⇒ (8x – 6x) = Rs. 1,86,000
⇒ 2x = Rs. 1,86,000
⇒ x = Rs. 93,000
Now,
The C's share of profit = Rs. (15 × 93,000)
⇒ Rs. 13,95,000
∴ The required share of C is 13,95,000

Question:
The graphs of the equations
\(4x + \frac{1}{3}y = \frac{8}{3}\) and \(\frac{1}{2}x + \frac{3}{4}y + \frac{5}{2} = 0\) intersect at a point P. The point P also lies on the graph of the equation:
Solution:
Given:
\(4x + \frac{1}{3}y = \frac{8}{3}\) and
\(\frac{1}{2}x + \frac{3}{4}y + \frac{5}{2} = 0\)
Calculation:
\(4x + \frac{1}{3}y = \frac{8}{3}\) ....(1)
\(\frac{1}{2}x + \frac{3}{4}y + \frac{5}{2} = 0\)
⇒ \(\frac{1}{2}x + \frac{3}{4}y = -\frac{5}{2}\) .....(2)
Now,
Multiplying the number by 3 in equation (1), we get
⇒ 12x + y = 8 ....(3)
Again, multiplying the number by 24 in equation (2), we get
⇒ 12x + 18y = -60 ...(4)
Now,
From equation (3) and (4), we get
⇒ (18y – y) = (-60 – 8)
⇒ 17y = -68
⇒ y = -4
Now, Putting the value of y in equation (3), we get
⇒ 12x – 4 = 8
⇒ 12x = 12
⇒ x = 1
So, P(1, -4)
Now,
According to given option
x + 2y – 5 = 0
⇒ (1 – 8 – 5) = 0
⇒ -12 is not equal to 0
So, It is not satisfying the point P
Again,
3x – y – 7 = 0
⇒ (3 + 4 – 7) = 0
⇒ (7 – 7) = 0
⇒ 0 = 0
It is satisfying the point P
Again,
x – 3y – 12 = 0
⇒ (1 + 12 – 12) = 0
⇒ (13 – 12) = 0
⇒ 1 is not equal to 0
So, It is not satisfying the point P
Again,
4x – y + 7 = 0
⇒ (4 + 4 + 7) = 0
⇒ 15 is not equal to 0
So, It is not satisfying the point P
∴ The point P also lies on the graph of the equation is 3x – y – 7 = 0

Question: In 6 minutes, \(\frac{4}{13}\) of a bucket is filled. How much time will it take to fill the remaining bucket?
Solution:
Given:
In 6 minutes, \(\frac{4}{13}\) of a bucket is filled
Calculation:
Total capacity of the bucket be 13 units
According to the question
4 unit is filled in 6 min
Then,
1 unit is filled in = \(\frac{6}{4}\) = \(\frac{3}{2}\) min
Now,
The rest part = (13 – 4) units = 9 units
1 unit is filled in = \(\frac{3}{2}\) min
Then,
9 unit is filled in = (9 × \(\frac{3}{2}\))
⇒ \(\frac{27}{2}\) min
⇒ 13 minutes 30 seconds
∴ Time taken to fill the remaining bucket is 13 minutes 30 seconds

Alternate Method
Remaining part of bucket = 1 - 4/13 = 9/13
Now, from the unitary method
4/13 part is filled in 6 min
1 part is filled in 6 × 13/4 min
9/13 part is filled in 6 × (13/4) × (9/13) = 27/2 min
∴ The required time is 13 min and 30 seconds.

Question: An article was sold for Rs. 716 after offering a discount of 10.5%. If a discount of 6.5% is given, then for how much (in Rs.) should it be sold?
Solution:
Shortcut Trick10.5% = 21/200
M.P = 200 units, Discount = 21 unit
S.P = 179 unit → 716
1 unit → 4
Now, 6.5% = 13/200
S.P = (200 - 13) unit
S.P = 187 unit = 187 × 4 [Since M.P in both ratio is same so same unit is used]
S.P = Rs. 748
∴ The requried S.P is Rs. 748.
Alternate MethodGiven:
An article was sold = Rs. 716
Discount = 10.5%
Formula used:
SP = MP(100 – Discount%)/100
Calculation:
Let the marked price be x
Now,
SP = MP(100 – Discount%)/100
⇒ 716 = \(x\frac{(100 - 10.5)}{{100}}\)
⇒ 716 = \(x\frac {89.5}{{100}}\)
⇒ 716 = \(\frac{89.5x}{{100}}\)
⇒ x = \(\frac{716 × 100}{{89.5}}\)
⇒ x = (8 × 100)
⇒ x = Rs. 800
Now,
At a discount of 6.5%
⇒ SP = MP(100 – Discount%)/100
⇒ SP = \(800 × \frac{100 - 6.5}{{100}}\)
⇒ SP = 800 × \(\frac {93.5}{{100}}\)
⇒ SP = (8 × 93.5)
⇒ SP = Rs. 748
∴ The required article sold at Rs. 748

Question: G is the centroid of a triangle ABC, whose sides AB = 35 cm, BC = 12 cm, and AC = 37 cm. The length of BG is (correct to one decimal place):
Solution:
Given:
G is the centroid of a triangle ABC,
AB = 35 cm
BC = 12 cm
AC = 37 cm
Concept used:
Circum-radius = ΔABC = Hypotenuse/2
The median of a triangle divides it into two triangles of equal areas
The centroid of a triangle divides the median in the ratio 2 : 1
Calculation:

We can say ΔABC is a right angle triangle 90° at B.
Point G is on BD
As we know, BD is circum-radius
⇒ Circum-radius = ΔABC = Hypotenuse/2
⇒ \(\frac{37}{{2}}\)
⇒ BD = BG + GD
⇒ BG : GD = 2 : 1 [The centroid of a triangle divides the median in the ratio 2 : 1], i.e.
\(\frac{GD}{BG}=\frac{1}{2}\)
Adding 1 to both the sides, we get:
\(\frac{GD}{BG}+1=\frac{1}{2}+1\)
\(\frac{GD+BG}{BG}=\frac{BD}{BG}=\frac{3}{2}\)
\(BG = \frac{2}{3}\times BD\)
\(BG = \frac{2}{3}\times \frac{37}{2}\)
BG = \(\frac{37}{{3}}\)
= 12.3 cm
∴ The length of BG is 12.3 cm

Question:
Study the given graph and answer the question that follows.

What is the ratio of the total production of fertilisers by country X in 2017 and country Y in 2020 to the production of fertilisers by country Z in 2019?

Question: A covered a distance of 240 km at a certain speed. Had his speed been 8 km/h less, then the time taken would have been one hour more for covering the same distance. How much time (in hours) will he take to cover a distance of 480 km at his original speed?
Solution:
Given:
Distance covered by A = 240 km
Had his speed been 8 km/h less, then the time taken would have been one hour more for covering the same distance
Formula used:
Speed = \(\frac{Distance}{{Time}}\)
Calculation:
Time taken by A to cover the total distance with speed x km/h = \(\frac{240}{{x}}\)
Time taken by A to cover the total distance with speed (x – 8) km/h = \(\frac{240}{{x-8}}\)
According to the question
⇒ \(\frac{240}{{x-8}}\) – \(\frac{240}{{x}}\) = 1
⇒ 240(\(\frac{1}{{x-8}}\) – \(\frac{1}{{x}}\)) = 1
⇒ (\(\frac{1}{{x-8}}\) – \(\frac{1}{{x}}\)) = \(\frac{1}{{240}}\)
⇒ (\(\frac{x-x+8}{{x(x - 8)}}\)) = \(\frac{1}{{240}}\)
⇒ \(\frac{8}{{x^2 - 8x}}\) = \(\frac{1}{{240}}\)
⇒ x2 – 8x = 1920
⇒ x2 – 8x – 1920 = 0
⇒ x2 – 48x + 40x – 1920 = 0
⇒ x(x – 48) + 40(x – 48) = 0
⇒ (x + 40) (x – 48) = 0
⇒ x = -40, 48 [Not taking the negative sign]
So, x = 48
Now,
Time taken to cover 480 km at his original speed = \(\frac{480}{{48}}\)
⇒ 10 hours
∴ The required time is 10 hours

Question: The value of \(\frac{{4{{\tan }^2}30^\circ + {{\sin }^2}30^\circ {{\cos }^2}45^\circ + {{\sec }^2}48^\circ - {{\cot }^2}42^\circ }}{{\cos 37^\circ \sin 53^\circ + \sin 37^\circ \cos 53^\circ + \tan 18^\circ \tan 72^\circ }}\) is:
Solution:
Given:
\(\frac{{4{{\tan }^2}30^\circ + {{\sin }^2}30^\circ {{\cos }^2}45^\circ + {{\sec }^2}48^\circ - {{\cot }^2}42^\circ }}{{\cos 37^\circ \sin 53^\circ + \sin 37^\circ \cos 53^\circ + \tan 18^\circ \tan 72^\circ }}\)
Formula used:
tan 30° = \(\frac{1}{{√ 3}}\)
sin 30° = \(\frac{1}{{2}}\)
cos 45° = \(\frac{1}{{√ 2}}\)
sec2θ – tan2θ = 1
sin2θ + cos2θ = 1
tanθ × cotθ = 1
Calculation:
\(\frac{{4{{\tan }^2}30^\circ + {{\sin }^2}30^\circ {{\cos }^2}45^\circ + {{\sec }^2}48^\circ - {{\cot }^2}42^\circ }}{{\cos 37^\circ \sin 53^\circ + \sin 37^\circ \cos 53^\circ + \tan 18^\circ \tan 72^\circ }}\)
⇒ \(\frac{4 × (\frac{1}{\sqrt3})^2 + (\frac{1}{2})^2.(\frac{1}{\sqrt2})^2 + (sec^248° – tan^248°)}{(sin53°.sin53° + cos53°.cos53° + tan 18°× cot18°)}\)
⇒ \(\frac{[4 × (\frac{1}{3}) + (\frac{1}{4}) × (\frac{1}{2}) + 1]}{(\sin^253° + \cos^253°) + 1}\)
⇒ \(\frac{[\frac{4}{3}+ \frac{1}{8} + 1]}{1+ 1}\)
⇒ \(\frac{[\frac{32+ 3+ 24}{24}]}{2}\)
⇒ [59/(24 × 2)]
⇒ 59/48
∴ The required value is \(\frac{59}{48}\).

Question: If the sum of two positive numbers is 65 and the square root of their product is 26, then the sum of their reciprocals is:
Solution:
Given:
The sum of two positive numbers = 65
The square root of their product = 26
Calculation:
Let the two numbers be a and b respectively
According to the question
⇒ a + b = 65
And, √ab = 26
⇒ ab = (26 × 26) = 676
Now,
The sum of the reciprocals = \(\frac{1}{{a}} + \frac{1}{{b}}\)
⇒ \(\frac{a + b}{{ab}}\)
⇒ \(\frac{65}{{676}}\)
⇒ \(\frac{5}{{52}}\)
∴ The sum of their reciprocals \(\frac{5}{{52}}\)

Question: The total surface area of a cylinder is 4092 cm<sup>2</sup> and the diameter of its base is 21 cm. What is 50% volume (in cm<sup>3</sup>) of the cylinder (nearest to an integer)?
Solution:
Given:
The total surface area of a cylinder = 4092 cm2
The diameter of the base = 21 cm
Formula used:
Total surface area of cylinder = 2πr(r + h)
Radius = \(\frac{Diameter}{{2}}\)
Volume of the cylinder = πr2h
Calculation:
The diameter of the base = 21
The radius of the base = \(\frac{21}{{2}}\)
According to the question
Total surface area of cylinder = 2πr(r + h)
⇒ 2 × \(\frac{22}{{7}}\) × \(\frac{21}{{2}}\)(\(\frac{21}{{2}}\) + h) = 4092​
⇒ (\(\frac{21}{{2}}\) + h) = 62
⇒ h = (62 – \(\frac{21}{{2}}\))
⇒ h = \(\frac{124-21}{{2}}\)
⇒ h = \(\frac{103}{{2}}\)
Now,
Volume of the cylinder = πr2h
⇒ (\(\frac{22}{{7}}\) × \(\frac{21}{{2}}\) × \(\frac{21}{{2}}\) × \(\frac{103}{{2}}\))cm3
⇒ \(\frac{71379}{{4}}\) cm3
Now,
50% volume of the cylinder = (\(\frac{1}{{2}}\) × \(\frac{71379}{{4}}\)) cm3
⇒ 8922 cm3
∴ The required 50% volume is 8922 cm3

Question: Eight years ago, the ratio of ages of A and B was 5 ∶ 4. The ratio of their present ages is 6 ∶ 5. What will be the sum (in years) of the ages of A and B after 7 years from now?
Solution:
Shortcut TrickAge ratio of A and B = 5 : 4 [8 years ago]
Age ratio of A and B = 6 : 5 [Present age]
Difference between the ratio of age of A or B = 1 unit
And this 1 unit → 8 years [Gap of age in years]
So, The present age of A = 6 units = 6 × 8 = 48
And the present age of B = 5 units = 5 × 8 = 40
So, The required sum of ages = (48 + 7) + (40 + 7)
⇒ 102 years.
∴ The required sum is 102 years.
Alternate Method
Given:
The ratio of ages of A and B , eight years ago = 5 : 4
The ratio of their present ages = 6 : 5
Calculation:
Eight years ago, the ratio of ages of A and B be 5x and 4x respectively
According to the question
⇒ \(\frac{(6x - 8)}{{(5x - 8)}} = \frac{5}{{4}}\)
⇒ 24x – 32 = 25x – 40
⇒ (25x – 24x) = (40 – 32)
⇒ x = 8
Now,
The present age of A = 6x = (6 × 8) = 48
The present age of B = 5x = (5 × 8) = 40
Now,
The sum of the ages of A and B after 7 years from now = (48 + 7) + (40 + 7)
⇒ (55 + 47) years
⇒ 102 years
∴ The required sum is 102 years

Question: In ΔPQR, S is a point on the side QR such that ∠QPS = \(\frac{1}{2}\) ∠PSR, ∠QPR = 78° and ∠PRS = 44°. What is the measure of ∠PSQ?
Solution:
Given:
∠QPS = \(\frac{1}{2}\) ∠PSR
∠QPR = 78°
∠PRS = 44°
Concept used:
The sum of all the sides of the triangle is 180°
An exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the two interior opposite angles
Calculation:

According to the question
∠QPS = \(\frac{1}{2}\) ∠PSR
Let ∠PSR = 2θ and ∠QPS = θ
We know that the sum of all the sides of the triangle is 180°
⇒ ∠QPR + ∠PRS + ∠RQP = 180°
⇒ 78° + 44° + ∠RQP = 180°
⇒ 122° + ∠RQP = 180°
⇒ ∠RQP = (180° – 122°)
⇒ ∠RQP = 58°
Now,
The exterior angle of ∠PSQ = 2θ
We know that an exterior angle of a triangle is equal to the sum of the two interior opposite angles
⇒ 2θ = θ + 58°
⇒ (2θ – θ) = 58°
⇒ θ = 58°
Now,
The value of ∠PSQ = (180° – 2θ)
⇒ (180° – 2 × 58°)
⇒ (180° – 116°)
⇒ 64°
∴ The required value of ∠PSQ is 64°

Question: If sin A = \(\frac{5}{13}\) and 7 cot B = 24, then the value of (sec A cos B) (cosec B tan A) is:
Solution:
Given:
sin A = \(\frac{5}{13}\)
7 cot B = 24
⇒ cot B = \(\frac{24}{7}\)
Formula used:
B2 = H2 – P2
H2 = B2 + P2
Calculation:

sinθ = \(\frac{P}{H}\)= \(\frac{5}{13}\)
By Pythagoras theorem
⇒ B2 = H2 – P2
⇒ B2 = (132 – 52)
⇒ B2 = (169 – 25)
⇒ B2 = 144
⇒ B = 12
sec A = \(\frac{H}{B}\) = \(\frac{13}{12}\)
tan A =\(\frac{P}{B}\) = \(\frac{5}{12}\)
Again,

cot B = \(\frac{B}{P}\) = \(\frac{24}{7}\)
By Pythagoras theorem
⇒ H2 = B2 + P2
⇒ H2 = (242 + 72)
⇒ H2 = (576 + 49)
⇒ H2 = 625
⇒ H = 25
cos B = \(\frac{B}{H}\) = \(\frac{24}{25}\)
cosec B = \(\frac{H}{P}\) = \(\frac{25}{{7}}\)
Now,
The value of (sec A cos B) (cosec B tan A)
⇒ (\(\frac{13}{12}\) × \(\frac{24}{25}\) × \(\frac{25}{{7}}\) × \(\frac{5}{12}\))
⇒ \(\frac{65}{42}\)
∴ The required value is \(\frac{65}{42}\)

Question: An article is sold at a certain price. If it is sold at \(33\frac{1}{3}\)% of this price, there is a loss of \(33\frac{1}{3}\)%. What is the percentage profit if the article is sold at 80% of its original selling price?
Solution:
Shortcut Trick
[Assume the selling price 300 so that it is easily divisible by 3, because 33.33% = 1/3]
Let the original selling price be 300 units
Selling price = 300 × (1/3) = 100
Loss = 33.33% = 1 : 3 [1 = Loss and 3 = C.P]
So, S.P = 2 units → 100
C.P = 3 units → 150
Now, New Selling Price = 80% of the original selling price
⇒ New Selling Price = 80% × 300 = 240
So, Required profit% = [(240 - 150)/150] × 100%
∴ The required profit% = 60%

Alternate Method
Given:
An article is sold at a certain price
If it is sold at \(33\frac{1}{3}\)% of this price, there is a loss of \(33\frac{1}{3}\)%
Formula used:
Profit = SP – CP
Profit% = \(\frac{Profit}{{CP}} × 100\)
Calculation:
Let the selling price be 100
If it is sold at \(33\frac{1}{3}\)%
⇒ SP = (\(\frac{1}{{3}}\) × 100)
⇒ SP = \(\frac{100}{{3}}\)= 33.33
Now,
there is a loss of \(33\frac{1}{3}\)%
⇒ (100 – 33.33)% of the cost price = 33.33
⇒ 66.67% of the cost price = 33.33
cost price = (\(\frac{33.33}{{66.67}} × 100\))
⇒ cost price = 50
Now,
80% of its original selling price = 80
Profit = (80 – 50) = 30
Profit% = (\(\frac{30}{{50}} × 100\))
⇒ 60%
∴ There required profit% is 60%
Shortcut Trick Let the marked price be 300
It is sold at \(33\frac{1}{3}\)% = (\(\frac{100}{{300}}\)) = \(\frac{1}{{3}}\)
SP = (\(\frac{300 × 1}{{3}}\)) = 100
Now,
There is still a loss of \(33\frac{1}{3}\)% = \(\frac{100}{{300}}\) = \(\frac{1}{{3}}\)
⇒ (1 – \(\frac{1}{{3}}\)) = \(\frac{2}{{3}}\)
So, CP = (100 × \(\frac{3}{{2}}\))
⇒ 150
Now,
Marked price = 300
Original price sold at 80%
⇒ New SP = \((\frac{80}{{100}} × 300)\)
⇒ SP = 240
Profit = SP – CP
⇒ (240 – 150) = 90
Profit% = (\(\frac{90}{{150}} × 100)\)
⇒ 60%
∴ The required profit is 60%

Question: The sum of the interior angles of a regular polygon A is 1260 degrees and each interior angle of a regular polygon B is \(128\frac{4}{7}\) degrees. The sum of the number of sides of polygons A and B is:
Solution:
Given:
The sum of the interior angles of a regular polygon A = 1260°
Each interior angle of a regular polygon B = \(128\frac{4}{7}\) = \(\frac{900}{{7}}\)
Formula used:
Sum of all interior angles = (n – 2) × 180°
Each interior angle = \(\frac{180(n - 2)}{{n}}\)
Where, n = number of sides of polygon
Calculation:
According to the question
The sum of the interior angles of a regular polygon A = 1260
Sum of all interior angles = (n – 2) × 180°
⇒ (nA – 2) × 180° = 1260°
⇒ (nA – 2) = \(\frac{1260}{{180}}\)
⇒ (nA – 2) = 7
⇒ nA = (7 + 2)
⇒ nA = 9
Now,
Each interior angle of a regular polygon B = \(\frac{900}{{7}}\)
Each interior angle = \(\frac{180(n - 2)}{{n}}\)
⇒ \(\frac{180(n - 2)}{{n}}\) = \(\frac{900}{{7}}\)
⇒ 180(nB– 2) = 900nB/7
⇒ 180nB – 360 = 900nB/7
⇒ (180nB – 900nB/7) = 360
⇒ (1260nB - 900nB)/7 = 360
⇒ 360nB/7 = 360
⇒ nB = 7
Now,
The sum of the number of sides of polygons A and B = (9 + 7)
⇒ 16
∴ The required sum is 16

Question: The base of a right prism is a triangle with sides 16 cm, 30 cm and 34 cm. Its height is 32 cm. The lateral surface area (in cm<sup>2</sup>) and the volume (in cm<sup>3</sup>) are, respectively:
Solution:
Given:
The base of a right prism is a triangle with sides = 16 cm, 30 cm and 34 cm.
Height = 32 cm
Formula used:
(Hypotenuse)2 = (Base)2 + (Perpendicular)2
Volume of Prism = Area of base × height = (\(\frac{1}{{2}}\) × b × h) × l
The lateral surface area of prism = Perimeter of base × height
Calculation:
According to the question
(Hypotenuse)2 = (Base)2 + (Perpendicular)2
⇒ (34)2 = (16)2 + (30)2
⇒ 1156 = (256 + 900)
⇒ 1156 = 1156
Now, we can say triangle is a right angle triangle
As we know,
Volume of Prism = \(\frac{1}{{2}}\) × b × h × l
⇒ \(\frac{1}{{2}}\) × 16 × 30 × 32 cm2
⇒ (8 × 30 × 32) cm3
⇒ 7680 cm3
Now,
The lateral surface area of prism = Perimeter of base × height
⇒ (16 + 30 + 34) × 32 cm2
⇒ (80 × 32) cm2
⇒ 2560 cm2
∴ The required value is 2560 and 7680.

Question: In ΔABC, M is the midpoint of the side AB. N is a point in the interior of ΔABC such that CN is the bisector of ∠C and CN ⊥ NB. What is the length (in cm) of MN, if BC = 10 cm and AC = 15 cm?
Solution:
Given:
In ΔABC, M is the midpoint of the side AB
N is a point in the interior of ΔABC such that CN is the bisector of ∠C and CN ⊥ NB
BC = 10 cm
AC = 15 cm
Concept used:
Midpoint theorem - The line segment in a triangle joining the midpoint of two sides of the triangle is said to be parallel to its third side and is also half of the length of the third side
Calculation:
Construction: Produce BN to P which meets AC at P.
And Join MN

According to the question
In ΔNPC and ΔNBC
∠N = ∠N [90°]
BC = PC [corresponding side]
BN = NP [corresponding angle]
⇒ ΔNPC ≅ ΔNBC
Hence, NB = NP (It means Point N is the midpoint of side BP)
And BC = PC = 10 cm
So, AP = AC – PC
⇒ AP = (15 – 10) cm
⇒ AP = 5 cm
Now, In ΔABP
M and N are the midpoints of AB and BP
So, According to the midpoint theorem
⇒ MN = \(\frac{AP}{{2}}\)
⇒ \(\frac{5}{{2}}\) cm
⇒ 2.5 cm
∴ The length of MN is 2.5 cm
Shortcut Trick
The using mid-point theorem,
In ΔBAP
MN = \(AP\over2\) = \(\frac{5}{{2}}\) = 2.5 cm

Question: A circle is inscribed in ΔPQR touching the sides QR, PR and PQ at the points S, U and T, respectively. PQ = (QR + 5)cm, PQ = (PR + 2)cm. If the perimeter of ΔPQR is 32 cm, then PR is equal to:
Solution:
Given:
PQ = (QR + 5)cm
PQ = (PR + 2)cm
Formula used:
Perimeter of the triangle ΔPQR =(PQ + QR + PR)
Calculation:

Let the value of QR be x
PQ = (QR + 5)
⇒ PQ = (x + 5)
Again,
PQ = (PR + 2)
⇒ (x + 5) = (PR + 2)
⇒ PR = (x + 5 – 2)
⇒ PR = (x + 3)
Now,
According to the question
The perimeter of the ΔPQR = 32 cm
⇒ (PQ + QR + PR) = 32 cm
⇒ (x + 5 + x + x + 3) = 32 cm
⇒ (3x + 8) = 32
⇒ 3x = (32 – 8)
⇒ 3x = 24
⇒ x = \(\frac{24}{{3}}\)
⇒ x = 8
Now,
The value of PR = (x + 3) = (8 + 3)
⇒ 11 cm
∴ The required value of PR is 11 cm

Question: If the sum of 40% of a number and 30% of the same number is 70, then the number is:
Solution:
Shortcut TrickLet the number be 10 unit
40% of 10 = 4, 30% of 10 = 3
According to the question
(4 + 3) unit → 70
7 unit → 70
1 unit → 10
10 unit → 100
∴ The required number is 100.
Alternate Method
Given:
The sum of 40% of a number and 30% of the same number = 70
Calculation:
Let the number be x
According to the question
⇒ (\(\frac{40}{{100}}\) × x + \(\frac{30}{{100}}\) × x) = 70
⇒ \(\frac{40x}{{100}}\) + \(\frac{30x}{{100}}\) = 70
⇒ \(\frac{70x}{{100}}\) = 70
⇒ x = \(\frac{100 \times 70}{{70}}\)
⇒ x = 100
∴ The required number is 100

Question: \(\rm \frac{{{{(1 + \sec θ \cos ec\,θ )}^2}{{(\sec θ - \tan θ )}^2}(1 + \sin θ )}}{{{{(\sin θ + \sec θ )}^2} + {{(\cos θ + \cos ec\,θ )}^2}}}\), 0° < θ < 90°, is equal to:
Solution:
Given:
\(\rm \frac{{{{(1 + \sec θ \cos ec\,θ )}^2}{{(\sec θ - \tan θ )}^2}(1 + \sin θ )}}{{{{(\sin θ + \sec θ )}^2} + {{(\cos θ + \cos ec\,θ )}^2}}}\)
Formula used:
secθ = \(\frac{1}{{cosθ }}\)
cosecθ = \(\frac{1}{{sinθ }}\)
secθ = \(\frac{1}{{cosθ }}\)
tanθ = \(\frac{sinθ }{{cosθ }}\)
sin2θ + cos2θ = 1
⇒ cos2θ = 1 – sin2θ
Calculation:
\(\rm \frac{{{{(1 + \sec θ \cos ec\,θ )}^2}{{(\sec θ - \tan θ )}^2}(1 + \sin θ )}}{{{{(\sin θ + \sec θ )}^2} + {{(\cos θ + \cos ec\,θ )}^2}}}\)
⇒ (1 +\(\frac{1}{{cosθ }}\) × \(\frac{1}{{sinθ }}\))2(\(\frac{1}{{cosθ }} - \frac{sinθ }{{cosθ }}\))2(1 + sinθ)/(sinθ + \(\frac{1}{{cosθ }}\))2 + (cosθ + \(\frac{1}{{sinθ }}\))2
⇒ \((\frac{sinθ.cosθ +1}{{sinθ .cosθ }})^2\)\((\frac{1 - sinθ }{{cosθ }})^2\)(1 + sinθ)/\((\frac{sinθ .cosθ +1}{{cosθ }})^2\) + \((\frac{sinθ .cosθ +1}{{sinθ }})^2\)
⇒ \((\frac{sinθ.cosθ +1}{{sinθ .cosθ }})^2\)\(\frac{(1 -sinθ)^2}{{cos^2θ }}\) × (1 + sinθ)/\(\frac{\ (sinθ .cosθ +1)^2}{{cos^2θ }}\) + \(\frac{ (sinθ .cosθ +1)^2}{{sin^2θ }}\)
⇒ \((\frac{sinθ.cosθ +1}{{sinθ .cosθ }})^2\)\(\frac{(1 -sinθ)^2}{{cos^2θ }}\) × (1 + sinθ)/\(\frac{sin^2\theta (sinθ .cosθ +1)^2+cos^2\theta (sinθ .cosθ +1)^2}{{sin^2θ.cos^2θ}}\)
⇒ \(\frac{(sinθ.cosθ +1)^2}{{sin^2θ .cos^2θ }}\)× \(\frac{(1 -sinθ)^2}{{1 - sin^2θ }}\) × (1 + sinθ)/\(\frac{(sinθ .cosθ +1)^2 sin^2θ + cos^2θ }{{sin^2θ.cos^2θ}}\)
⇒ \(\frac{(1 -sinθ)^2}{{1 - sin^2θ }}\) × (1 + sinθ)
⇒ \(\frac{(1 -sinθ)^2}{{(1 - sinθ)(1 + sinθ ) }}\) × (1 + sinθ)
⇒ 1 – sinθ
∴ The required value is 1 – sinθ

Question: A solid metallic cuboid of dimensions 12 cm × 54 cm × 72 cm is melted and converted into 8 cubes of the same size. What is the sum of the lateral surface areas (in cm<sup>2</sup>) of 2 such cubes?
Solution:
Given:
Length of cuboid = 12 cm
Breadth of cuboid = 54 cm
Height of the cuboid = 72 cm
It is converted into 8 cubes of the same size
Formula used:
Volume of the cuboid = lbh
Volume of cube = a3
Lateral surface area of the cube = 4a2
Calculation:

According to the question
⇒ lbh = 8 × a3
⇒ (12 × 54 × 72) = 8 × a3
⇒ (12 × 54 × 9) = a3
⇒ a3 = 5832
⇒ a = 18 cm
Now,
The sum of the lateral surface area of the two such cubes = (4a2 + 4a2)
⇒ 8a2
⇒ 8 × 18 × 18 cm2
⇒ 2592 cm2
∴ The required sum is 2592 cm2

Question:
Study the given graph and answer the question that follows:

The average production of fertilisers by country Z in 2017, 2018 and 2020 is what percentage more than the average production of fertilisers by country X in 2018 and 2020?
Solution:
Calculation:
The average production of fertilisers by country Z in 2017, 2018 and 2020 = \((\frac{330 + 360 + 420}{{3}})\)
⇒ \(\frac{1110}{{3}}\)
⇒ 370
The average production of fertilisers by country X in 2018 and 2020 = \((\frac{240 + 260}{{2}})\)
⇒ \(\frac{500}{{2}}\)
⇒ 250
Required percentage = \(\frac{(370 - 250)}{{250}} × 100\)
⇒ \(\frac{120}{{250}} × 100\)
⇒ (24 × 2)%
⇒ 48%
∴ The required average production is 48%

Question: What is the difference (in Rs.) between the interests on Rs. 50,000 for one year at 8% per annum compounded half yearly and yearly?
Solution:
Shortcut Trick
Rate% for 1 year when compounded yearly = 8%
Rate% for 1 year when compounded half-yearly = [4 + 4 + (4 × 4)/100]%
⇒ 8.16%
Difference between rate percent = 8.16% - 8% = 0.16%
Difference between interest = 0.16% of 50000 = 80
∴ The required difference is Rs. 80
Alternate Method
Given:
Principal = Rs. 50,000
Rate = 8%
Formula used:
A1 = P(1 + r)t
A2 = P(1 + \(\frac{r}{{2}}\))2t
Calculation:
When interest is yearly
A1 = P(1 + r)t
⇒ 50,000 × (1 + \(\frac{8}{{100}}\))1
⇒ (50,000 × \(\frac{108}{{100}}\))
⇒ Rs. 54,000
Now,
When interest is half-yearly
A2 = P(1 + \(\frac{r}{{2}}\))2t
⇒ 50,000 × (1 + \(\frac{8}{{200}}\))2
⇒ (50,000 × \(\frac{208}{{200}}\) × \(\frac{208}{{200}}\))
⇒ (5 × 52 × 208)
⇒ Rs. 54,080
Now,
The difference between the interests on compound half-yearly and yearly = Rs. (54,080 – 54,000)
⇒ Rs. 80
∴ The required difference is Rs. 80

Question: The radius of the base of a cylindrical tank is 4 m. If three times the sum of the areas of its two circular faces is twice the area of its curved surface, then the capacity (in kilolitres) of the tank is:
Solution:
Given:
The radius of the base of a cylindrical tank = 4 m
Three times the sum of the areas of its two circular faces is twice the area of its curved surface
Formula used:
Area of circle = πr2
Curved surface area of cylinder = 2πrh
Volume of the cylinder = πr2h
Calculation:
Let h be the height of the cylinder
According to the question
Three times the sum of the areas of its two circular faces is twice the area of its curved surface
⇒ 3 × (πr2 + πr2) = 2 × 2πrh
⇒ 6πr2 = 4πrh
⇒ (6 × π × 4 × 4) = (4 × π × 4 × h)
⇒ h = 6 m
Now,
The capacity of the tank = πr2h
⇒ (π × 4 × 4 × 6)
⇒ 96π
∴ The required capacity of the tank is 96π

Question: 4 men and 5 women can complete a work in 15 days, whereas 9 men and 6 women can complete it in 10 days. To complete the same work in 7 days, how many women should assist 4 men?
Solution:
Given:
4 men and 5 women can complete a work in 15 days,
9 men and 6 women can complete it in 10 days.
Calculation:
According to the question
Total work = Total work
⇒ (4m + 5w) × 15 = (9m + 6w) × 10
⇒ (60m + 75w) = (90m + 60w)
⇒ (90m – 60m) = (75w – 60w)
⇒ 30m = 15w
⇒ 2m = 1w
⇒ m : w = 1 : 2
Total work = (4m + 5w) × 15
⇒ (4 × 1 + 5 × 2) × 15
⇒ (4 + 10) × 15
⇒ (14 × 15)
⇒ 210
Let x women assist 4 men to complete the work in 7 days, then
⇒ (4 × 1 + x × 2) × 7 = 210
⇒ (4 + 2x) = \(\frac{210}{{7}}\)
⇒ (4 + 2x) = 30
⇒ 2x = (30 – 4)
⇒ 2x = 26
⇒ x = 13
∴ 13 women assist 4 men
Shortcut TrickAccording to the question
(4m + 5w) × 15 = (9m + 6w) × 10
⇒ 60m + 75w = 90m + 60w
⇒ 30m = 15w
⇒ m : w = 1 : 2
Total work = (4m + 5w) × 15
⇒ (4 + 10) × 15
⇒ 210
According to the question
⇒ (4 + 2 × x) × 7 = 210
⇒ 28 + 14x = 210
⇒ 14x = 182
⇒ x = 13
∴ The required women is 13

Question: The radius of a solid right circular cone is 36 cm and its height is 105 cm. The total surface area (in cm2) of the cone is:
Solution:
Given:
The radius of a solid right circular cone = 36 cm
Height = 105 cm
Formula used:
l2 = r2+ h2
Total surface area of cone = πr(r + l)
Calculation:
According to the question
Radius (r) = 36 cm
Height (h) = 105 cm
l2 = r2+ h2
⇒ l2 = (362 + 1052)
⇒ l2 = (1296 + 11025)
⇒ l2 = 12321 cm2
⇒ l = 111 cm
Now,
Total surface area of cone = [π × 36(36 + 111)] cm2
⇒ (36π × 147) cm2
⇒ 5292 π cm2
∴ The required total surface area is 5292 cm2

Question: The income of A is 80% of B's income and the expenditure of A is 60% of B's expenditure. If the income of A is equal to 90% of B's expenditure, then by what percentage are the savings of A more than B's savings?
Solution:
Shortcut Trick
Ratio Method
Income of A : B = 4 : 5
Expenditure of A : B = 3 : 5
Here, 90% of B's expenditure = 5 × 90% = 9/2
So, Income of A = 9/2 unit
For making income of A, 9/2, we have to multiply the 1st ratio by 9/8
Income of A : B = [4 : 5] × 9/8 = 9/2 : 45/8
Expenditure of A : B = 3 : 5
Saving of A : B = (9/2 - 3) : (45/8 - 5) = 3/2 : 5/8 = 12 : 5
∴ Required% = [(12 - 5)/5] × 100% = 140%

Alternate Method
Given:
The income of A is 80% of B's income
The expenditure of A is 60% of B's expenditure
The income of A is equal to 90% of B's expenditure
Calculation:
Let the income of B be 100x
So,
Income of A = (100x × \(\frac{80}{{100}}\))
⇒ 80x
For B's expenditure
90% of B's expenditure = A's income
B's expenditure = \(\frac{90}{{100}}\) = 80x
⇒ (\(\frac{100 × 8x}{{9}}\))
⇒ \(\frac{800x}{{9}}\)
For A's expenditure
A's expenditure = 60% of B's expenditure
⇒ (\(\frac{60}{{100}}\) × \(\frac{800x}{{9}}\))
⇒ \(\frac{160x}{{3}}\)
Now,
Savings of A = Income of A – Expenditure of A
⇒ (80x – \(\frac{160x}{{3}}\))
⇒ \(\frac{240x-160x}{{3}}\)
⇒ \(\frac{80x}{{3}}\)
Now,
Savings of B = Income of B – Expenditure of B
⇒ (100x – \(\frac{800x}{{9}}\))
⇒ \(\frac{900x-800x}{{9}}\)
⇒ \(\frac{100x}{{9}}\)
Now,
Required percentage increase = \((\frac{80x}{{3}} - \frac{100x}{{9}})\)/(\(\frac{100x}{{9}}\)) × 100
⇒ \((\frac{240x - 100x}{{9}})\)/(\(\frac{100x}{{9}}\)) × 100
⇒ (\(\frac{140x}{{9}}\) × \(\frac{9}{{100x}}\) × 100)
⇒ 140%
∴ The required percentage is 140%

Question: S and T are points on the sides PQ and PR, respectively, of ΔPQR such that PS × PR = PQ × PT. If ∠Q = 96° and ∠PST = ∠PRQ + 34°, then ∠QPR = ?
Solution:
Given:
S and T are points on the sides PQ and PR, respectively, of ΔPQR
PS × PR = PQ × PT
∠Q = 96°
∠PST = ∠PRQ + 34°
Concept used:
We know that the sum of all the sides of triangle is 180°
Calculation:

PS × PR = PQ × PT
⇒ \(\frac{PS}{{PQ}} = \frac{PT}{{PR}}\)
So, from the converse of thales theorem
ST || QR
So, ∠Q = ∠PST = 96° [By corresponding angles]
Given, ∠PST = ∠PRQ + 34°
⇒ 96° = ∠PRQ + 34°
⇒ ∠PRQ = (96° – 34°)
⇒ ∠PRQ = 62°
Now,
We know that the sum of all the sides of triangle is 180°
⇒ ∠PQR + ∠PRQ + ∠QPR = 180°
⇒ 96° + 62° + ∠QPR = 180°
⇒ 158° + ∠QPR = 180°
⇒ ∠QPR = (180° – 158°)
⇒ ∠QPR = 22°
∴ The required value of ∠QPR is 22°.

Question: If 3 tanθ = \(2\sqrt 3\) sinθ, 0° < θ < 90°, then the value of \(\rm \frac{{\cos e{c^2}2\,\theta + {{\cot }^2}2\,\theta }}{{{{\sin }^2}\,\theta + {{\tan }^2}2\,\theta }}\) is:
Solution:
Given:
3 tanθ = \(2√ 3\) sinθ
Formula used:
tanθ = \(\frac{sinθ }{{cosθ }}\)
cos 30° = \(\frac{√3}{{2}}\), cosec 60° = \(\frac{2}{{√3}}\)
Cot 60° = \(\frac{1}{{√ 3}}\), sin 30° = \(\frac{1}{{2}}\), tan 60° = √3
Calculation:
We have 3 tanθ = \(2√ 3\) sinθ
⇒ 3 \(\frac{sinθ }{{cosθ }}\) = 2√3 sinθ
⇒ \(\frac{3}{{cosθ }}\) = 2√3
⇒ cosθ = \(\frac{√3}{{2}}\) = cos 30°
⇒ θ = 30°
Now,
The value of \(\rm \frac{{\cos e{c^2}2\,θ + {{\cot }^2}2\,θ }}{{{{\sin }^2}\,θ + {{\tan }^2}2\,θ }}\)
⇒ \(\frac{cosec^2 60° + cot^2 60° }{{sin^2 30° + tan^2 60° }}\)
⇒ \(\frac{(\frac{2}{{√3}})^2 \ + \ (\frac{1}{{√3}})^2} {(\frac{1}{{2}})^2 \ + \ (\sqrt3)^2}\)
⇒ \(\frac{\frac{4}{3} + \frac{1}{3}}{\frac{1}{4} + \frac{3}{1}}\) = \(\frac{\frac{5}{3} }{\frac{13}{4} }\)
⇒ \(\frac{{20}}{{39}}\)
∴ The required value is \(\frac{{20}}{{39}}\).

Question: A trader gains 25% by selling an article with 20% discount on its marked price. If the cost price of the article increases by 30%, then how much discount (in %) should he offer on the same marked price to gain 15% of the profit?
Solution:
Shortcut TrickLet the marked price be Rs. 100
SP of the article = 100 × \(\dfrac{80}{100}\) = Rs. 80
CP of the article = 80 × \(\dfrac{100}{125}\) = Rs. 64
New, CP of the article = 64 × \(\dfrac{130}{100}\) = \(\dfrac{416}{5}\) = Rs. 83.2
New, SP of the article = 83.2 × \(\dfrac{115}{100}\) = \(\dfrac{1913.6}{20}\) = Rs. 95.68
Discount% = \(\dfrac{100-95.68}{100}\) × 100
⇒ \(\dfrac{4.32}{100}\) × 100= 4.32%
∴ The required discount percentage is 4.32
Alternate Method Given:
A trader gains 25% by selling an article with 20% discount on its marked price
The cost price of the article increases by 30%
Formula used:
SP = MP – Discount
SP = Profit + CP
Discount = MP – SP
Discount% = \(\frac{Discount}{{MP}}\) × 100
Calculation:
Let the marked price be 100 and the cost price be x
SP = MP – Discount
⇒ SP = (100 – 20) = 80
Now,
Profit gains = 25%
⇒ x + 25% of x = 80
⇒ x + \(\frac{25}{{100}}\) × x = 80
⇒ x + \(\frac{x}{{4}}\) = 80
⇒ \(\frac{4x+x}{{4}}\) = 80
⇒ \(\frac{5x}{{4}}\) = 80
⇒ 5x = 320
⇒ x = 64
CP = 64
Now,
The cost price of the article increases by 30%
⇒ 64 + 30% of 64
⇒ 64 + \(\frac{30}{{100}}\) × 64
⇒ 64 + \(\frac{192}{{10}}\)
⇒ 64 + 19.2
⇒ New CP = 83.2
Now,
According to the question
Discount he offers on the same marked price to gain 15% of profit
SP = Profit + CP
⇒ (15% of 83.2) + 83.2
⇒ (\(\frac{15}{{100}}\) × 83.2) + 83.2
⇒ (\(\frac{1248}{{100}}\)} + 83.2
⇒ (12.48 + 83.2)
⇒ 95.68
Now,
Discount = MP – SP
⇒ (100 – 95.68)
⇒ 4.32
Discount% = \(\frac{Discount}{{MP}}\) × 100
⇒ (\(\frac{4.32}{{100}}\) × 100)
⇒ 4.32%
∴ The required discount percentage is 4.32

Question: If an article is sold for Rs. 355, there is a loss of 29%. At what price (in Rs.) should it be sold to gain 31% of profit?
Solution:
Given:
SP of the article = Rs. 355
Loss = 29%
Formula used:
CP = \(\frac{SP}{{100 - Loss}} × 100\)
Calculation:
SP of the article = Rs. 355
Loss = 29%
CP = \(\frac{SP}{{100 - Loss}} × 100\)
⇒ \(\frac{355}{{100 - 29}} × 100\)
⇒ (\(\frac{355}{{71}} × 100\))
⇒ 500
CP = Rs. 500
Now,
For 31% gain
⇒ SP = (500 × \(\frac{131}{{100}}\))
⇒ 655
SP = Rs. 655
∴ The required SP is Rs. 655
Shortcut TrickCP SP New SP
100 71 131
⇒ 71 unit = 355
⇒ 1 unit = 5
Then,
⇒ 131 unit = (131 × 5) = Rs. 655
∴ The required SP is Rs. 655

Question: The value of \(\rm \frac{{3({{\cot }^2}47^\circ - se{c^2}43^\circ ) - 2({{\tan }^2}23^\circ - \cos e{c^2}67^\circ )}}{{\cos e{c^2}(68^\circ + \theta ) - \tan (\theta + 61^\circ ) - {{\tan }^2}(22^\circ - \theta) + \cot (29^\circ - \theta )}}\) is:
Solution:
Given:
\(\rm \frac{{3({{\cot }^2}47^\circ - se{c^2}43^\circ ) - 2({{\tan }^2}23^\circ - \cos e{c^2}67^\circ )}}{{\cos e{c^2}(68^\circ + θ ) - \tan (θ + 61^\circ ) - {{\tan }^2}(22^\circ - θ) + \cot (29^\circ - θ )}}\)
Formula used:
tan(90° – θ = cotθ
sec2θ – tan2θ = 1
If (a + b) = 90° then, tan A = cot B
cosec2θ – cot2θ = 1
Calculation:
\(\rm \frac{{3({{\cot }^2}47^\circ - se{c^2}43^\circ ) - 2({{\tan }^2}23^\circ - \cos e{c^2}67^\circ )}}{{\cos e{c^2}(68^\circ + θ ) - \tan (θ + 61^\circ ) - {{\tan }^2}(22^\circ - θ) + \cot (29^\circ - θ )}}\)
⇒ \(\rm \frac{{3({{\tan }^2}43^\circ - se{c^2}43^\circ ) - 2({{\tan }^2}23^\circ - \sec{c^2}23^\circ )}}{{\cos e{c^2}(68^\circ + θ ) - \tan (θ + 61^\circ ) - {{\tan }^2}(22^\circ - θ) + \cot (29^\circ - θ )}}\) [tan(90° – θ = cotθ and tan2θ – sec2θ = -1]
⇒ \(\rm \frac{{3({{\tan }^2}43^\circ - se{c^2}43^\circ ) - 2({{\tan }^2}23^\circ - \sec{c^2}23^\circ )}}{{\cos e{c^2}(68^\circ + θ ) - \tan (θ + 61^\circ ) - {{\cot }^2}(68^\circ + θ) + \cot (29^\circ - θ )}}\) [If (a + b) = 90° then, tan A = cot B]
⇒ \(\rm \frac{{3({{\tan }^2}43^\circ - se{c^2}43^\circ ) - 2({{\tan }^2}23^\circ - \sec{c^2}23^\circ )}}{{\cos e{c^2}(68^\circ + θ ) - {{\cot }^2}(68^\circ + θ) )}}\)
Now, Taking minus common
⇒ \(\rm \frac{{-3({{-\tan }^2}43^\circ + se{c^2}43^\circ ) +2({{-\tan }^2}23^\circ + \sec{c^2}23^\circ )}}{{\cos e{c^2}(68^\circ + θ ) - {{\cot }^2}(68^\circ + θ) )}}\) [cosec2θ – cot2θ = 1]
⇒ \(\rm \frac{{-3 +2}}{{1 }}\)
⇒ -1
∴ The required value is -1

Question:
What is the area (in unit squares) of the region enclosed by the graphs of the equations
2x – 3y + 6 = 0, 4x + y = 16 and y = 0?
Solution:
Given:
2x – 3y + 6 = 0
4x + y = 16
y = 0
Formula used:
Area of triangle = \(\frac{1}{{2}}\) ∣x1(y2 – y3) + x2(y3 – y1) + x3(y1 – y2)∣
Calculation:

2x – 3y + 6 = 0
⇒ 2x – 3y = -6 ....(1)
4x + y = 16 ....(2)
Multiplying equation (2) by 3
⇒ 12x + 3y = 48 ...(3)
Now,
Adding (1) and (3), we get
⇒ (2x + 12x) = (48 – 6)
⇒ 14x = 42
⇒ x = 3
Now, Putting the value of x in equation (1)
⇒ 2 × 3 – 3y = -6
⇒ 6 – 3y = -6
⇒ -3y = -1
⇒ y = (-1 – 3) = 4
So,(x1, y1) = (3, 4)
Now,
We put y = 0 in equation (2)
⇒ 4x + 0 = 16
⇒ 4x = 16
⇒ x = 4
So,(x2, y2) = (4, 0)
Again,
We put y = 0 in equation (1)
⇒ 2x – 0 = -6
⇒ 2x = -6
⇒ x = -3
So,(x3, y3) = (-3, 0)
Now,
Area of triangle = \(\frac{1}{{2}}\) ∣x1(y2 – y3) + x2(y3 – y1) + x3(y1 – y2)∣
⇒ \(\frac{1}{{2}}\)∣3(0 – 0) + 4(0 – 4) + (-3)(4 – 0)∣
⇒ \(\frac{1}{{2}}\)∣0 + (-16) + (-12)∣
⇒ \(\frac{1}{{2}}\)∣-16 – 12∣
⇒ \(\frac{1}{{2}}\)∣-28∣
⇒ 14 [Negative sign is always treated as positive in modulus]
∴ The required value is 14.

Alternate Method
When we find the vertices from the given equations
Given:
2x – 3y + 6 = 0
4x + y = 16
y = 0

Area of triangle = \(\frac{1}{2}\) × Base × Height
Area of triangle = \(\frac{1}{2}\) × 7 × 4 = 14

Question: A tap can fill a tank in \(5\frac{1}{2}\) hours. Because of a leak, it took \(8\frac{1}{4}\) hours to fill the tank. In how much time (in hours) will the leak alone empty 30% of the tank?
Solution:
Given:
Time taken by A to fill the tank = \(5\frac{1}{2}\) hours = \(\frac{11}{{2}}\) hours
Because of leak, the tank filled in = \(8\frac{1}{4}\) hours = \(\frac{33}{{4}}\) hours
Formula used:
Work = Efficiency × Time
Calculation:
Per hour efficiency of tap = \(\frac{2}{{11}}\)
Let the per hour efficiency of the leak be x
According to the question
⇒ \(\frac{2}{{11}}\) + x = \(\frac{4}{{33}}\)
⇒ x = (\(\frac{4}{{33}}\) – \(\frac{2}{{11}}\))
⇒ x = (\(\frac{4 - 6}{{33}}\))
⇒ x = \(\frac{-2}{{33}}\) [The negative sign shows it is draining the tank]
The total time taken by the leak to empty the 30% of the tank = (1/\(\frac{2}{{33}}\)) × \(\frac{30}{{100}}\) hours
⇒ (\(\frac{33}{{2}}\) × \(\frac{30}{{100}}\)) hours
⇒ \(\frac{99}{{20}}\) hours
∴ The required time taken by the leak to empty the 30% of the tank is \(\frac{99}{{20}}\) hours
Shortcut TrickLet the total capacity of the tank be 33 [LCM of 11 and 33]
Efficiency of A to fill the tank = (\({33}\)× \(\frac{2}{{11}}\)) = 6
Combined Efficieny of (leak + A) = 33 ÷ (33/4) = 4
Efficiency of Leak = 4 - 6 = - 2
30% of the tank = \(33 × \frac{30}{{100}}\)
⇒ \(\frac{99}{{10}}\)
Now, the Required time to empty = (99/10) ÷ 2
∴ The required time is \(\frac{99}{{20}}\) hours

Question: A saves 35% of his income. If his income increases by 20.1% and his expenditure increases by 20%, then by what percentage do his savings increase or decrease? (correct to one decimal place)
Solution:
Given:
Saving of A = 35%
Income of A increases = 20.1%
Expenditure of A increases = 20%
Formula used:
Saving = (Income – Expenditure)
Calculation:
Let the income of A be 100
Then,
Expenditure of A = (100 – 35) = 65
Now,
Income of A increases = 20.1%
⇒ (100 × \(\frac{20.1}{{100}}\)) = 20.1
Expenditure of A increases = 20%
⇒ (65 × \(\frac{20}{{100}}\)) = 13
So, Saving = (Income – Expenditure)
⇒ (20.1 – 13) = 7.1
The percentage of saving increased = \((\frac{7.1}{{35}} \times 100)\)
⇒ \(\frac{710}{{35}}\) = 20.3%
∴ The required percentage is 20.3% of increase

Question: The value of \(\left( {2\frac{6}{7}of4\frac{1}{5} \div \frac{2}{3}} \right) \times 5\frac{1}{9} \div \left( {\frac{3}{4} \times 2\frac{2}{3}of\frac{1}{2} \div \frac{1}{4}} \right)\) is:
Solution:
Concept Used:
Follow the BODMAS rule according to the table given below:

Calculation:
\(\left( {2\frac{6}{7}of4\frac{1}{5} ÷ \frac{2}{3}} \right) × 5\frac{1}{9} ÷ \left( {\frac{3}{4} × 2\frac{2}{3}of\frac{1}{2} ÷ \frac{1}{4}} \right)\)
⇒ \((\frac{20}{{7}}of\frac{21}{{5}}÷ \frac{2}{{3}}) × \frac{46}{{9}} ÷ (\frac{3}{{4}} × \frac{8}{{3}} of \frac{1}{{2}} ÷ \frac{1}{{4}}\))
